  4239. Initially I noted the batteries would die very quickly, then the volume of water being pumped decreased - then this morning - it totally quit working.
  4240. If we're playful we'll spray each other with it if someone tries to grab it first.
  4241. />The soft battery cover can easily be damaged by the wrong tool to open it
  4242. may try and track down the older one as this needs some engineering improvements.
  4243. This oral irrigator works very well, but I wish it were a little larger because I need to refill it before I'm done flossing my teeth.
  4244. It cleaned between my teeth very well and only freaked me out a little bit.
  4245. I think I had \\"prototypes\\" in the past, though this model is very much the same.
  4246. irrigators are, at their most basic level, a small water reservoir, some form of electricity, and a thin nozzle to spray high pressure water between your teeth.
  4247. In order to use it, you have to awkwardly hold the top and bottom halves of the product just far enough apart

All Reviews

  1. I really like this product and bought one for my wife as well as my brother. It works great! We all use it daily and it make a big difference. I much prefer it to flossing.
  2. Works great, I use it in the shower every morning! It makes my mouth feel like i just went to the dentist. I got braces at 45 and had a hard time with flossing, this does the trick. I do change the batteries every two weeks to keep it working up to par. I also run the blue part and the nozzle through the dishwasher (top rack) once a week, it does tend to get a little gunky. If it broke i would definitely buy another one!
  3. The item did a mediocre job. The stream was weak and did not remove particles that were heavily stuck. Didn't do the job for me.
  4. I have implants that require irrigation and this does the trick. Would recommend it for sure!
  5. This works just fine. My mouth feels a lot better and my hygienist likes the results.
  6. 2nd time buying this. loved it since could use in shower, totally portable (runs on AA), large reservoir but after several years, water seeped into battery compartment. then last year bought a rechargeable cordless waterpik - w/in a year couldn't hold charge, recharging base was an irritant due to cord, obviously need to be near outlet, reservoir small and challenge to refill. using panasonic now for a month, know why i loved it so much before. i use rechargeable battery w/ downside needing to open compartment more risking corrosion. highly recommended, would give it 5 stars if wasn't a bit bulky. for the price, can't go wrong.
  7. Great for traveling-- can't live without my waterpik on a daily basis.
  8. Much easier to clean than the WaterPik. Also the water flow adjustments make it much less painful than the other brands. Even the slow speed on the Water Pik makes me cringe to use it. The lack of a cord makes it easily portable, and safer in the bathroom. I tried many other brands before settling on the one. It is also cheaper.
  9. Good basic irrigator/losser. Battery power lasts quite awhile. Stream of water is strong and effective.
  10. ......Already like this much better. It collapses smaller, has more power, uses batteries.Overall I believe this is a product I would have bought first if I'd not had to stay with the Water-Pik [because 2 others failed within a year and they were good enough to replace]
  11. we love being able to clean our teeth inside the shower. No worries of water spraying everywhere. Great product, thank you.
  12. I like this guy because he doesn't take up much space on my bathroom counter. The drawback to that being the water reservoir empties quickly and I have to refill at least once per session. Something I didn't think about when i was browsing...not necessarily a draw back but a consequence to small size. It does was it says and is easy to use no cumbersome charger. So overall I'm a fan.
  13. This is a great oral irrigator. It works on batteries which last a long time and is great for travelling as well as it doesn't take up much space in the bathroom.
  14. I've wanted a water flosser for years, and I was so excited to get this one. I'm so disappointed in it. The water chamber is very small and the pressure is just not that good. It does not do what I had hoped - get everything from between teeth. I wish I had returned it because I just don't use it like I had hoped.
  15. So far so good. My previous irrigator required very regularly charging and then just stopped working. I suspected this model would not be as powerful as the rechargeable version but it has proved to be just as strong. Only gripe is that the applicator is a little sharp and will cause bleeding of the gums if you touch them too hard.
  16. Works fine but eats batteries!!!
  17. At first this product is great. In a few months of use it gets black particles trapped in the blue case portion.<br />Hard to get particles out so you have dirty water to rinse mouth. I have not been able to find a way to separate the blue portion for a full clean of the product. Until this issue is resolved this product is not recommended.
  18. I am used to using an electric water irrigator and this one with batteries just doesn't seem to have the oomph that the electric does. I take it when I travel as it is better than nothing, but for at home, use an electric one.
  19. This is my second Panasonic water pic. The first one wore out after 3 years of constant use. Originally bought it for travel, but found I used it more than the big-tank model that was way more expensive. Two-speed does the job and is just much quicker fill and use. Be sure to follow directions to empty the water. Change the batteries once in a while but not as often as you would think. I can only use the low speed when the batteries are fresh; high speed with fresh batteries might loosen a few fillings.
  20. When flying, packing space is of maximum importance. I didn't want to take up space with my waterpik from home and I didn't want my water pik to get broken in transit. So, I bought this portable model. I took extra batteries and didn't have to use them on my 4 day trip. I did fill the resevoir 2 times with each use. Not for everyday use but, as a travel accessory, perfect!
  21. For one who has a filling in every tooth, this product came uears too late. Great dental health tool. Government should provide one for everyone.
  22. My only difficulty with this item is that the nozzle is hard for me to remove. It's slippery plastic, and fits so tightly that it's difficult to grip without slippage. Perhaps not everyone would have this difficulty, but I had a Panasonic water flosser a long time ago that didn't have this problem. Still, it does a good job of cleaning in conjunction with a toothbrush.<br />My dentist has a sign in his office: Q. Do I need to floss all of my teeth? A. No, just the ones you want to keep.
  23. I retired my old Panasonic and purchased a new one -so nice to get that strong power stream back which the old one lost over time.
  24. I really enjoyed this water pik when I first bought it. It works great, easy to use and gives great pressure.<br />However within a few months it started acting up and doesn't work as well. The battery compartment is all corroded and gross.<br />Not for long term or everyday use.
  25. My first water pic. It gets the job done although I imagine the larger ones have a little more force.<br />Have to fill it twice to do whole mouth...but no big deal.<br />Great for traveling ....just came back from vacation and easy to pack! Couldn't do that with more traditional pic.
  26. Have had similar model same brand for &#62;10 years; bought second for weekend home. After brushing and flossing it still finds food particles to clean out. Great product
  27. This is a good product although sometimes I need to fill it twice. The advantage to a regular water pik which I have also used is that I can close it up and keep it in my medicine chest.
  28. Have used this for a while now, and it works just fine. My teeth have just the wrong size gap in a couple of places, and the Panasonic Flosser power spray is very handy to finish what a toothbrush just can't do.
  29. My dentist recommended a water flosser for my gum issues. I keep this in my shower, as it is too messy to use in the sink, but I love it. Compact, portable and super easy to use. The reservoir holds enough water that I can do my whole mouth without refilling. I wasn't sure I would really use this, but since I moved it into the shower, I use it every single day. Love it!!
  30. And what a great value! I like the compactness of this irrigator, and the spray jets have 2 speeds in case you have softer gums. I sometimes worry about whether all the water drains or not, but for e past cole months I have not had any problems nor reason to worry. I never had an irrigator before, so I was a little worried. This seems to do a great job and not take much space. As an added bonus, it's ability to collapse into itself makes travel easier
  31. I got this product because I just wanted to up my dental hygiene regiment. I love it. It's just enough pressure without hurting my gums. The only issue is that it leaks a little as you're using it, but other than that I would totally recommend this product to my friends and family.
  32. At first, the unit looks bulky. However, one must understand that the reservoir volume is necessary, on top of the motor and the batteries. I would have love a little stronger jet but for a traveling unit, this is a well-designed irrigator.
  33. This is the second device I have purchased from Amazon. After seeing my first one, my wife also wanted one. They work great. I can't believe how much the toothbrush leaves behing.
  34. Great! I was using the rechargeable ones, which die in 12-18 months. The two AA bateries lasted 40 days, at this rate Panasonic is superior.
  35. It is small, compact and packs easily. I use it at home every day but also like the portability of it for travel. Works just as advertised.
  36. It works just fine. I had an earlier version for several years. It finally broke and I replaced it and I'm still happy with it.
  37. This Panasonic Oral Irrigator is efficient, has two speeds, takes up very little space and is portable. The speed on \\"2\\" is quite strong (with fresh batteries). The two AA batteries last about one month with daily use. I am extremely pleased with it. I wish I had included an order for the second tip along with the original order.
  38. This battery-operated unit is easy to handle and convenient to store,but it has less power and capacity than wired units. My dentist considers it adequate for travel use but not for regular at-home use.
  39. Excellent device, exceeded my expectations! Highly recommend.
  40. The Panasonic Oral Irrigator is not meant to be a replacement for the home product, which has a large tank,enabling you to clean your entire tooth surfaces at one time. To do a very good job with the Panasonic you must refill its tank at least 2 times. The force of the cleaning drops as the reservoir is depleted. Therefore, you have to repeat the product on the last teeth done before the refill. In addition, you are warned not to use rechargeable batteries. Regular ones last about 20 minutes. If you are prepared for these limitations, the Oral Irrigator is much better than having nothing and will do its intended job.
  41. Great time-saver--don't have to floss nearly as often! Wish I'd bought it sooner. Works great and I travel alot and it's easy to pack as well. Worth every penny.
  42. I think this is a great tool for the traveller because of its compact size and battery operation. It works fairly strong as a water-pick but the water container is a little small so one may need to refill it a second time to thouroughly clean the gum. For the money, I think it is a good buy. I used to own the 'waterpik' model which I also liked but this one is comparable but more compact and the design more clever for travels.
  43. Looked all over for this item for my husband who has used these for a long time. No one carried them. When I finally found someone who could order the pricer was much higher. He likes this very much and is happy. So happy I thought of ordering through Amazon.
  44. I was hesitant to purchase because it is more of a portable/travel irrigator, but was desperate to get my teens to start using. Their dentist recommended I purchase one because their gums weren't as healthy as they could have been. I knew that it would be a novelty at first, but hoped it was easy enough that they would continue. Well my youngest (14) is using it every day. She used it with her braces on and is still with them off. My son (17) used it every day at first, but then tapered off a bit. He is still using it once or twice a week, which I figure is better than not at all. Both of them really like it. At first they had a little trouble (fun) getting use to the water squiring at them, but with some practice they got it under control. We haven't been back to the dentist for a formal report on the health of their gums, but I can see that their teeth are clean without that white film they tend to miss when they just brush and in between their teeth is nice and clean like they flossed. Now my husband wants one! I would definitely purchase one again. I hope this helps someone with their decision because I count on these reviews when I'm purchasing an item on line. I gave it 4 stars because I didn't personally use it.
  45. don't know how long it will last but my first impression is that it is really good.right amount of pressure for daily use..small enuf for travel.easy to use. Gave it less than 5 stars because the reservoir needs to be re filled for a longer wash . and batteries...cannot use rechargeable as mentioned in the instructions .I think the manufacturer should have put in an option to charge it instead of the consumer spending money on batteries.All in all a good product.

This is my second Panasonic Oral Irrigator. I had to replace my first one because the little trap door where you fill it with water popped off and got left behind on my last vacation. So be aware of that. They have made a few improvements, including a two stage power switch if you don't want to run it full blast. I recommend this product.

  56. Our old Waterpic finally fell apart after years of service. The pressure on the thing could knock your eye out if you didn't aim carefully! I didn't want to spend a bundle on a replacement and wasn't adverse to saving space in our very small (no countertop) bathroom. I decided the price was right and the reviews were good so I'd give the Panasonic a shot. I'm very pleased with this mini version. The pressure is not as good as the Waterpic but, that said, it is definitely good enough. The size is ideal and I like not having to plug anything in. I do have to fill the reservoir twice but that's doable. It uses almost no counter space and is easily portable. I would not only recommend it but am thinking of giving one as a gift. It's a user friendly, nifty little gadget that gets the job done without a fuss!
  57. This is my 3rd portable panasonic irrigator for our family and were are 30+ year oral irrigators (mostly corded waterpiks). I'm overall pleased with the Panasonic units and they last well. This new model as a slightly larger water holding capacity than it's predecessor, although both are adequate for most days. Not too tough to refill for another shot if needed. Another plus is the two speeds. The big negative is that both speeds are less powerful than the older model. So I gave this one to my wife who likes the lower pressure pulses. I use NiMH rechargeable batteries in all of them, changing them every two weeks for best pressure. I've also experienced the on/off switch getting difficult to turn. You can pry off the switch and clean under it. I even filed the plastic detent clip down a bit to reduce the difficulty of turning it on. I give the new unit a 3 star and older model a 4 star, since pulse pressure is of #1 importance. Now if this new unit had speed 1 as high and speed 2 even harder pulses, they would really have a 5 star irrigator.
  58. i purchased this panasonic oral irrigator ( water pic type device ) just before we went on vacation,, and it worked great (not as good as my home unit, but a whole lot better than none) i used it every night , the only thing was i had to fill it at least 2 times, but i feel that was a small thing to do considering the benfit i recieved.

This is over a six month or so period. I was just tired of buying them. But we liked the portability of being able to take them on vacations. Panasonic's product works well. I have finally replaced the batteries for the first time. I imagine it's about two months or so. Also the price is right. I was just going to buy the old standby for $60 or $70 when this product caught my eye. I figured for $30 or so it was worth the try. Smartest thought I've had in a while.   65. This is a highly effective way to get loose particles out of the spaces between my crowded teeth. The unit has a powerful jet at the high setting, which I use almost all the time. I still do not know how to clean inside of lower part of the mouth as I can't adjust the nozzle to keep water in side the mouth. Water speed is decent and holds firmly in my hand.   107. I have used a original &#34;Water Pick&#34; years ago, but never like it. This Panasonic version seems to work very well, is a lot quieter in operation, and easy to use. The unit is &#34;Odd&#34; looking, but quite functional. It takes up very little space on the counter top, and you don't have to plug it in.   108. It has helped me reduce the times I need a hygienist to clean my teeth from 3 times a year, back to two. Keep an eye on the nozzle, they eventually get plugged and the unit will not function well and will go through batteries very quickly. Right after a battery change it has a lot of power, as the month goes on, not so much. Water resistant, works in the shower or over the sink.   112. I bought the irrigator to replace a full-size irrigator because I didn't want a tube that coils and collects mold. This irrigator fulfilled that with its short, straight tube. It holds enough water to do the entire mouth if you keep it moving. What I don't like about it is that it is awkward to hold and maneuver in the mouth and shutting off the unit is extremely difficult once your hand and irrigator are wet from irrigating. A push-button would have been a much better control. All-in-all, I'm okay with it because I feel it is much more sanitary than most irrigators with the long, coiled tube. It's small and compact, so I'll be able to take it along when I travel.

  115. This irigator is successor of Panasonic EW1270AC, which I bought 2 years ago. From my point of view the older model was better - you were able to store the nozzle inside of irigator body and save the space, which is not possible with new model. Also the two speeds are not an advantage - you will use only the stronger stream anyway. Common problem of all these portable models is following: they loose their power as time goes by. So you have to buy a new one each two years. But for me as an often traveling person, there is no other possibility. Panasonic models are great, you will be satisfied with them for sure. The big advantage is use of standard AA batteries, so you will have no problem when you are traveling all around the world.

I travel twice a month to the same two destinations and leave one at each place in case I forget to pack one. This Panasonic Oral Irrigator EW-DJ10-A is very efficient with two pulse strengths, looooong battery life, easy to fill, easy to collapse for storage or travel.   122. I have been using an oral irrigator type product for many, many years. I loved the Waterpik handheld, rechargeable; but about once a year, the battery would no longer recharge. After several years of paying too much for Waterpik, I then tried a Profloss 4190 Waterflosser for $19.99. It also worked for about a year, hooks up to the water faucet so no batteries or recharging, but not portable. Eventually, the water pressure from the faucet would pop the hose out of the connection to the faucet. Recently, I was very excited to find the Oral Irrigator by Pure Enrichment, $29.99, which uses double A batteries, but I quickly discovered that it had absolutely no water pressure whatsoever so I have returned it. My quest to find a portable, battery powered oral irrigator is now over. After reading many reviews, I purchased the Panasonic Portable Oral Irrigator EW-DJ10-A. When I read the complaints that the pressure was too hard, I knew this was the one for me. I've only used it for two days, twice a day every day, but I love everything about it!!! The collapsible (for travel) water reservoir is completely adequate. It does not spray all over the room if you keep it in your mouth. The on/off button is perfectly located. And the water pressure is to die for!!!!! I'm in love!!!

After 5 months of regular use it stopped charging and will no longer charge the unit so it is only useful for a doorstop. The Panasonic unit uses AA batteries and there is no charging problem. The pulsating action is less vigorous with the Panasonic but it seems to do the job and I am thrilled with it and so is the dentist. He will no longer recommend Waterpik

I stand by all I said in my previous review below. -- I use this (or very similar) type waterpik for 5 years, and find that they usually last a year or so (at 2-4 quarts/day). I think the rubber rings on the piston wear out, and you know the \\"end of life\\" is near when there is water in the battery compartment and the pressure is slightly reduced. I am very happy with the product - BUT ONLY AFTER MODIFICATION! I take off the silly little tank, and then attach a 2-3ft vinyl tube with an inside diameter the same size as the outside diameter of the unit's tube. I then fill a gallon jug with water, and insert the vinyl tube into that. Works great! I love the low hassle and easy storability of the unit. Batteries last about 3 gallons. My experience with the original Water-Pik(tm) is that they are utter pieces of junk!!! They break and fail and are engineered like a cheap piece of crap!!!

  183. My dentist advised me that I have dental pockets as deep as 11 mm! Most of my teeth are 4 - 7 mm. One tooth is the one with the 11 mm depth. The first week I used it, I could not believe the horrible tasting crud that was hiding under my gum line! After 2 weeks, I notice my gums are stronger, because - instead of being able to fit 4 strand of dental floss between some teeth, I can only fit 2 strands. My gums are no longer red and swollen!<br /><br />This product is great WHEN it works. I bought this product September of 2013. It is November 1, 2013 - and it has totally quit working. I only used it 2x per day, and always drained the water. Initially I noted the batteries would die very quickly, then the volume of water being pumped decreased - then this morning - it totally quit working. Because of lack of durability, I downgraded the rating. Extremely disappointed in Panasonic.<br /><br />November 30, 2013 - Update<br />I closely examined this product, and noticed there is a tiny filter on the bottom of the intake tube. I partially closed the unit. I used the curved nozzle tip to gently move the tube outside of the chamber. Sure enough, the bottom of the filter was clogged. I took a sewing needle and carefully removed the clog, making sure not to damage the filter. I have upgraded my rating. Got it to work like new!<br /><br />October 6, 2014<br />My tooth hardly wobbles! Love it. This unit is still working, however I noticed that the water stream was weaker, even if I changed batteries, so I replaced the nozzle. It works like New!<br /><br />March 20, 2015<br />I upgraded the Stars because the unit is still working beautifully. I am going to order another one for traveling.

However, mine just died and it was my fault that it did. I periodically soak it in a weak bleach water solution to rid it of any mildew that accumulates. I don't have to do this often as I saved the inner cardbaard packaging which allows me to leave this open after used and let it drain. However, at times, it does get some mildew under areas where parts overlap. This last time I soaked it, I forgot to close the battery compartment, from which I had removed the batteries. It got wet and now doesn't work. My fault! It has worked well and faithfully for the last two years. I'll let it dry some more and see if it starts to work again. If not, I will definitely order another as it has become an essential part of my daily routine and makes such a difference in my oral care and health.

  207. Just got the Panasonic Oral Irrigator and tried it out. I've never used one of these things before, so I can't compare it to any other brands. This review is based solely on my experience with this one product. My first thought on turning it on was, \\"Yikes, this really is messy!\\" I'd read other reviews that said it was messy, but I figured maybe it was just clumsiness or user error (no offense). What I mean by \\"messy\\" is that you're going to get water everywhere. I got water all over the mirror, my shirt, the bathroom counter, the walls ... everywhere.<br /><br />Design Flaw<br />I believe the Panasonic Oral Irrigator suffers from a major design flaw: the power switch. It's a locking switch, which means when you switch it to the \\"on\\" position, it stays on until you switch it off. So, you open your mouth, aim the irrigator, and flip the switch and water begins pulsating out of the nozzle. If you're not expecting the ensuing mess, you might frantically try to turn it off again. But you've probably moved your finger away from the switch, so you have to find it again while simultaneously trying to manage the watery mess. A better design would have been a button like most blenders have that must be held down to keep the power on. Once you let go of the button, the power should cut off.<br /><br />Update: It's been a few months and since I'm now willing to say \\"I like it\\", I'm upping my rating to four stars. With practice I've gotten better at handling the power switch, though I still accidentally spray a stray stream of water around the bathroom once in a while.
  208. I received this item for less than a week and very please with the product. It's cordless, compact, easy to use and as effective as the ones with cord. I wish I had known this sooner.
  209. Works well does the job!
  210. This Panasonic oral irrigator is terrific. It is easy to use and portable. But most importantly, it clears out food particles that brushing and flossing miss. My gums feel much better. I highly recommend this product.
  211. Saw this and decided to try it because it is much more compact and easier to handle when traveling. It seems to work as well as the full size pic. It does take a bit of getting used to. I know since I purchased this item there are now better travel oral irrigators that are probably much nicer than this one; however, I was so pleased with mine that I ordered an additional four to give to my adult children. They seem to be very pleased with using it. I like it best for:<br />travel<br />no need to hook up to the faucet or fill a vase<br />doesn't have to sit out on the counter<br />the mouth piece disconnects for cleaning and sanitizing.
  213. I bought the Panasonic Oral Irrigator to bring to Thailand since it's gotten excellent reviews on Amazon. I was not disappointed. The unit had more than enough power with the two different power selections...I was a bit skeptical about this but it definitely held it's own. I used this at least once a day during my two week vacation and the battery is still working strong (it requires two AA batteries) even with the generics ones it came with. I would imagine the batteries could last over a month with daily use. I love the fact that it uses disposable batteries since I've had poor luck with rechargeable portable irrigators from Waterpik (they have two different models and both were horrible) and I didn't have to worry about the different voltage other countries use. With the collapsing water reservoir, this unit stored easily in my toiletry pouch. It also had a little storage compartment for the pick jet. This is quite an ingenious design. Kudos to the designer(s) at Panasonic. Amazon has these for sale for under $30 which is truly a bargain...the only drawback is that it won't be in stock for at least another month. I'm going to order another anyway...I highly recommend this for people with braces :)
  214. This works O.K. as a travel unit, but it really doesn't hold much water, and I found it frustrating to start and stop flossing just to fill the tank. It is certainly not a substitute for a full sized model if you are serious about flossing.

  224. It's easy to use, powerful and uses AA sized batteries so you don't have to keep charging it or have yet another charger plugged into your wall. My whole family loves this teeth cleaner and we rush to see who can use it first in the morning. If we're playful we'll spray each other with it if someone tries to grab it first. We all like the way it spurts in your mouth cleaning everything between your teeth. Sometimes we all line up and wait for the person ahead get finished. I figure by Christmas I might have enough money saved to splurge for a second unit to reduce the number of fights we have.<br /><br />I'm thinking of using rechargeable batteries to see if there's any difference. Rechargeable batteries are usually 1.2 volts, not 1.5 volts like alkaline batteries are so with 2 batteries installed it would mean the unit is getting 0.6 less volts than if alkaline batteries were used. I'll update my review after I do some testing.<br /><br />Oh yeah, to play a prank on my wife I filled it full of vanilla extract. She noticed right away and squirted me with it. All is well though because we kissed and made up. I liked the vanilla taste on her lips.<br /><br />I highly recommend this product. So does my wife and five kids. Oh yeah, instead of taking our dog to the vets and spend a fortune to have its teeth cleaned we use this unit instead. The dog likes it because we fill it with water mixed with a few drops of liquid beef bullion. I kind of like chicken bullion the best but everyone has a preference.

  226. I bought this item as a gift for my girlfriend, who had recently been fitted with braces. She loved it, as it got a lot of the gunk out of the braces and was also quite compact (relatively speaking).<br /><br />I liked it so much that I bought one for myself. However, after going through batteries quickly, I switched to rechargeable batteries and they work great. I think that you're not \\"supposed to\\" use rechargeables, but there's no reason not to that I can see. I used the Sanyo Eneloop batteries, but I recently bought my girlfriend rechargeable Evereadys and they too work just fine.<br /><br />During my last visit to the dentist's office, she said I was doing a good job flossing. I told her that I had started using this oral irrigator and she was in favor of it. However, she was quite clear that it is not a replacement for flossing. But she thought that using this device along with flossing, brushing with Sonicare and then using a good mouthwash (Listerine) was a good routine.<br /><br />Also, be aware that you can open the device for cleaning by very gently pulling the upper housing from the lower tank. You'll obviously want to clean the thing from time-to-time.<br /><br />Open the battery compartment with a quarter or the like. If you turn it enough, the cover will lift from the lower housing.<br /><br />Overall, I really like the Panasonic Oral Irrigator and use it daily. It's well-built, works great and is inexpensive. 5 stars all the way!
  227. It's a bit big to hold in your hand. Tends to make it more drippy. But, it does the job, was good price and I can take it with me. All those are pluses.
  228. I use the Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser at home to clean my teeth, but for cleaning my teeth at work after lunch, or for those times when I'm travelling, this Panasonic Oral Irrigator can't be beat. The reservoir chamber is small, yes, but it can be easily refilled. I fill it twice for each use -- once for my lower teeth, and once for my upper. I also add a liquid \\"soap\\" to the reservoir -- a mixture of mouthwash and toothpaste (the toothpaste is liquified in the mouthwash). So far the irrigator has had no problem pumping this \\"soap\\". I purchased mine about 8 months ago and started by using two, AA alkaline batteries. The irrigator was good at removing food, but not perfect -- I had to use the Waterpik at home to get rid of the deeper stuff (including the plaque stuck just under my gumline). Despite the warning against using rechargable batteries, I went ahead and starting using NiMH rechargeable AA batteries, but I noticed the unit wasn't pumping as hard as with the alkaline, and so I had even more difficulty getting the daytime plaque removed. I decided I needed more voltage. I purchased a lithium-ion 14500 battery (very close in size to a AA, but the nubby tab is reduced in height). That comes out of the charger at 4.0 volts. Couldn't use two of those, so I made a dummy battery out of a #10 bolt, #10 washers, and fasteners (to keep the washers attached) and ground the dummy battery down to size. That made the irrigator too powerful, and I felt like my gums were being laser-cut away. Also, the lithium-ion battery started to fade after about 20 seconds (the power of the irrigator went down). To get the lithium-ion voltage down, I made another dummy battery but with two bolts connected to a central plastic tube and two diodes in parallel (taken from an old AC adapter) to reduce the voltage -- it connected the two bolts together. They reduced the voltage by 0.3 volts, and after trying again, the irrigator no longer felt like it was cutting my gums away, but the diodes would heat up, and the 14500 li-ion battery would fade as before, plus that battery would only get through two days of lunch cleaning before it needed recharging (I could use the NiMH batteries for two weeks without problem). My recent attempt now is using PowerGenix NiZn rechargeable AA batteries. They are advertized at 1.6 volts, but I measured them out of the charger at 1.8 volts. Now the irrigator is at the same pumping power as the li-ion battery was with the diodes, but the NiZn batteries don't fade, and no more hand-making dummy batteries. Time will tell how long the NiZn batteries will last, but so far they are the best match with this oral irrigator. Oh, I should mention the irrigator is also great for returning to work after a dental visit. On low setting, I use it to flush out all the old amalgam bits the dentist left in my mouth. UPDATE 3/12/2011 The NiZN batteries, while performing well in the Panasonic irrigator, have resulted in a little too much pressure in the long term. The increased water pressure has forced an opening under my gumline between two front teeth causing bleeding. I'm now using one NiZN battery with a Duracell low-self discharge NiMH battery. This has reduced the pressure enough to stop cutting open the gumline in the one spot while giving enough pressure to effectively clean my teeth and gums. I think ultimately this irrigator would do better with a strength setting from 1-10 much like the Waterpik's plug-in model, then I wouldn't have to experiment so much with different battery combinations. Despite all of my high-voltage experiments with this irrigator, it has held up and continues to run fine. Update 5/31/2011 I continue to use one PowerGenix NiZn battery with one Duracell NiMH battery for the best balance of power without tearing up my gums. In this setup, I can use this irrigator for a week in my lunchtime cleaning before having to switch out batteries. I keep another pair of NiZn/NiMH batteries ready to go, so I'm never without good power. At the end of the week, I take the used NiZn/NiMH battery pair home and recharge them (each in their own chargers, I have to use the special charger that came with the NiZN for the NiZN battery). I also switched from a toothpaste/mouthwash cleaning solution to a Dove soap/mouthwash cleaning solution. The toothpaste has micro-fine silica, and I was afraid that in a pressure washer like this irrigator it would blast away enamel and dental work. It may have contributed to that pocket in my gumline when I was using two NiZn batteries in the irrigator. I take a cheese grater with a turn handle and insert the bar of Dove soap into the grater, then turn the handle many times to produce soap bits that land in a large, microwaveable measuring cup. Then I fill the measuring cup with mouthwash and microwave the mixture to heat it up. I take one of those bamboo sticks that are found in the kitchen accessory sections of department stores and stir the mixture until all soap bits are dissolved. I then pour that mixture back into the empty mouthwash container. For dispensing, I have a used, plastic, shrimp cocktail container that I fill and use to squirt the soap in the Waterpik irrigator for home. For work, I use an empty, see-through, one-dollar shampoo container as found at stores like Target or Walgreens (meant for travel kits) and squirt a little soap solution from that into the Panasonic irrigator. Despite using these various soaps and different power levels, the Panasonic irrigator continues to run fine.

  251. I first purchased the waterpik cordless at double the price and had problems with it. With my WaterPik I never used any of them as they serve no real function. The only thing that could use a bit of work is the button design, it takes some getting used to and sometimes it is hard to shut off and easy to go from low to high but not low to off. I can live with this minor quirk but if that were remedied it would be a perfect 5 star. If you can't live without an oral irrigator this is your model - it can't be beat on either the price or quality level.

  256. It does everything I wanted as promised. Easy to use, easy to put together and I love that it is portable and uses batteries.
  257. This is an offensively bad product. Beyond awful. Do not under any circumstances buy it.<br /><br />Oral irrigators are, at their most basic level, a small water reservoir, some form of electricity, and a thin nozzle to spray high pressure water between your teeth. This product seems carefully designed to be the worst irrigator possible.<br /><br />Design flaws:<br />1. For some unfathomable reason, this product is actually two moving pieces, you have to slide the two pieces apart in order to fill the water reservoir, but once you do, there is nothing keeping the two pieces apart. Which means that if you were to set the product down on the counter while it is full of water, the two pieces of it would slide back together, draining the entire reservoir onto the counter. That's right, you can't even set this product down without draining it completely<br />2. In order to use it, you have to awkwardly hold the top and bottom halves of the product just far enough apart that they don't collapse and spray water everywhere, but not so far apart that the hose inside the reservoir stops working<br />3. The product is so long, heavy, and unwieldy that it is extremely difficult to aim inside your mouth<br />4. The pressure is so high that if you miss your teeth (which you will a lot), it will hit the roof of your mouth, your tongue, and your uvula. This hurts, a LOT<br />5. The power button is positioned such that it is nested between the two pieces and can't be turned on or off without a lot of work. This is almost impossible to deactivate without looking, which means you have to take a high pressure water jet out of your mouth just to deactivate it<br />6. The pressure is so high that unless you close your mouth entirely, it will spray everywhere. This product made a huge mess all over my counter, and the only way to prevent this was to get on my knees, kneel over the sink, and use it with my head in the sink bowl, which, due to the ridiculous length and shape, means that aiming the device was haphazard at best<br />7. When I took the product out of it's packaging, it smelled like moldy vomit. The stench was absolutely nauseating, and I had to spend 5 minutes scrubbing the outside and the inside of the product as best I could. I then drained three entire reservoirs worth of soapy water to try and clean out and rinse the tube inside, and even THEN, it still didn't work. My mouth now smells like vomit, so thanks for that.<br /><br />Basically, to use this product, you have to slide it open, fill the reservoir, close the reservoir lid, hold the product vertically by both the top and bottom halves, keep them separated, put your head in the sink bowl, activate the device's power without even being able to see it, then awkwardly spray the product around inside your mouth, frequently hitting and damaging the roof of your mouth and your uvula, occasionally choking and gagging when the high pressure spray goes down your throat, and having water occasionally spray everywhere.<br /><br />Now, the most important question is: once you get past the offensively bad design, does the product actually work? NO. It does not. I have several troublesome teeth where food frequently gets caught, and as an experiment, I used three full reservoirs worth of water trying to clean these trouble spots. Then I took dental floss and checked the result. The irrigator did absolutely nothing. It completely failed to get anything out of my teeth.<br /><br />This product is a joke, it doesn't even come close to working, it is designed so badly that I am stunned it ever made it out the door, and it came covered in something that smelled and tasted like rancid vomit. Look somewhere else, please don't waste your money on this.

During this period encountered low water pressure out of nozzle and noticeable water leakage between water tank and motor body when in use (seal not effective).   262. This is a great tool to keep teeth and gums squeeky clean. The power is from two AA batteries and they last a good long time.   263. I've owned three of the Panasonic oral irrigators. The first two units I owned were the predecessor model with the darker blue color. Both the old and new have some great features: A powerful motorized pump and a nicely sized water resevoir you can collapse for travel. Even the telescoping nozel can be removed and stowed away. Very cool. The current model has improved on the previous design. The resevoir is larger. This makes it possible to clean out your whole mouth by only filling the resevoir once. One design flaw with both models is the hinged door on the resevoir. You swing it open to add water. However, I lost the hinge door on my first two units about a year. After a while, the plastic pegs that hold it in place weaken and the door comes loose. I expect the same thing to eventually happen with the unit I just bought since it is built the same way. Another way the unit can fail is the motor. On my first unit, the motor progressively lost power after a year or so of daily use. Overall, the Panasonic irrigators are an effective tool for keeping teeth clean and I will continue to buy them. I once owned a Waterpik model and it was inferior to the Panasonic: A smaller resevoir, you could not collapse it for travel, and the water flow was weak. Panasonic offers a superior product. As an aside, my dentist told me to continue to floss. The irrigators can remove large stuff stuck between teeth, but are not as effective at removing food that sits below the gum line.
  264. This is our second panasonic irrigator. We really like this product. Our dental checkups have been much improved with it's use. It also leaves a wonderful clean feel to our mouths. We read the directions this time, and use regular batteries instead of rechargeables. For the 2 of us regular batteries last 2 weeks with once a day use. It has 2 speeds, but we always use the high speed (which is not really high).

  271. I've had the EW-DJ10-A for about a month and think it performs well. If you've used a corded irrigator before there aren't any real surprises.It takes a little getting used to the water tank and getting it positioned so it seals correctly. Not a huge issue. I got it for the portability. Uses AA Battery's. (supplied) The tank quantity is small so you might have to refill the tank two or three times to complete your cleaning. It also takes some practice, as with any irrigator, to get used to a pattern of angling the tip as you go around your mouth. Two water jet speeds. Highest might be too much for some. All-in-all, cleaning takes 2-3 mins. Good value for the price of about $30. As a dentist would probably tell you, it works best when you floss first but is better that nothing if you don't. No free lunch.
  272. Works as advertised. Good pressure. Inexpensive and effective alternative to flossing that's easier on your gums. Would buy again.
  273. I've been using Panasonic oral Irrigator for years without a problem. Just got this model for my wife. It is even better than what I have. Bigger water tank, and 2 speeds are nice features to have. I only suggest that you buy a charger and rechargeable batteries. Not only it is better for your wallet, but they last 10 times longer than regular batteries. I use Sanyo, but I am sure there are other good solutions.
  274. The unit I received must have been on the shelf for a while -- the batteries only lasted through the test phase. However, with a new set of 2 AA's it works fine. Although it's not as strong as my electric WaterPik and the reservoir must be filled a couple of times per use, it's compact and convenient for travel, which is just what I needed it for. For crowns, braces, and/or bridges, an oral irrigator of some kind is essential to remove all the gunk stuck between and around them. Moreover, the dentist always comments on how healthy my gums appear!
  275. We've had this waterpick since a few month and it has been working flawlessly.<br />We use rechargeable battery, even though the doc says not too, and that still works fine. You need to dry it carefully before opening the battery compartment, so there would not be any humidity going in.<br />I also bought a set of replacement pick, so we have each ours; they have neat little color rings to identify them.<br />It is quite convenient not to have any cable holding the contraption, and the power of the jet is plenty enough to do the job. And we take it with us when we travel.<br />Edit:<br />After a bit more than a year of using this, some mold has appeared in the water compartment, which is impossible to clean. Especially at the o-ring, which started to leak.<br />We asked if we could get a new o-ring from the manufacturer, but the part is not provided, so we could not open it and make sure it would close again.<br />In the end, we threw it away and replaced it with another brand/model.
  276. The product is handy. The power is a little short and the battery life too. But no worries with the power supply in various countries!
  277. it look like very good,Haven't used yet.
  278. I use an oral irrigator that attaches to the faucet when at home, The faucet attached irrigator is not something I can easily use in a hotel room or on a camping trip. I was glad to find this unit for when I am on the road. It has as much cleaning power as the faucet irrigator.
  279. 15 years ago I purchased a Panasonic irrigator that did not have much power, so I tried 2 other models from other companies. I am really pleased with this one. It is exceptionally good for a battery operated model. It effectively removes debris that one cannot get with floss and brushing, and is compact for travelling.
  280. I got this because I finally gave up trying to convince myself that I \\"will\\" start flossing on a daily basis. I'm in my 30's now so it was time to give up on that fantasy and try finding something that will make the daily chore breezy enough to do so I will do it every day. I got this one because it's cordless and uses regular batteries.<br /><br />I agree with the people who say it's messy to use. I absolutely CANNOT use this without getting water all over myself and on the mirror. So I have to wear my bathrobe whenever I want to floss so that I don't get all wet. this is ok for me because I take my shower at night and then put on my robe and then brush my teeth / floss. I don't know if other irrigators are just as messy as this one because this is my first one. When I first used it my gums bled and it hurt! But now after a couple of weeks of using it, it doesn't hurt at all any more. No more bleeding either. Now if I could just get it to stop spraying water everywhere...<br /><br />Update: After a few weeks of use, I've managed to not spray water everywhere and am able to keep it off my clothes and just in my mouth. Didn't think it would be possible. In my case it took a while to practice.
  281. My dentist suggested using a water irrigator. This was about half the price of other products in the same category. I've been using it for a few weeks now and am very satisfied. It does such a good job cleaning that I don't need to floss any longer. I tried flossing a few times after using the irrigator and there were no leftovers. I'm considering buying another one for my wife.

  283. Easy to use but no cover for the head

  286. What a great product. Thank Panasonic.
  287. I suppose that any product as dreadfully named as the Panasonic EW-DJ10-A is a product that's likely to perform its intended task with single minded efficiency. After all, if you're going to let your engineers rather than your marketing people name your product, it's pretty clear that you're placing a high premium on functionality and somewhat less of an emphasis on form. Sure enough, the Panasonic's little irrigator isn't the most aesthetically appealing product in the world, but it gets the job done. Namely, it holds a respectable amount of water, shoots said water into one's mouth, and in the process dislodges food particles. So what more could one want in an oral irrigator? Well, a little more power would be nice. I also own a hydrofloss irrigator, and this little chap simply doesn't compare in the pressure department. It's not bad at all, but it just doesn't have the kick that the hydrofloss sports. On the plus side, it's MUCH queiter than my hydrofloss, which sounds like it's experiencing the mechanical equivalent of an epileptic seizure every time I hit the switch. Also, in the unit's defense, there' simply no way that a product operated by a couple of double AAs is going to have the same amount of power as a plug-in unit. Which bring's me to the Panasonic's best point, portability. It's small size is simply perfect for traveling or when one's away from the house. Overall, I've been very pleased with this unit. The build quality is excellent and it does what it's designed to do. I can't comment on reliability or battery life, since I've only used it a few times, but so far it's been great. Highly recommended.
  288. This unit is battery driven and very weak. It is very inconvenient to use as the bottle is attached to the spray unit.
  289. I am accustomed to a regular water pic and this one is just not powerful enough to be satisfactory. Also, the small plastic piece which holds the water n broke shortly after I purchased this item which means I have to hold my thumb over it in order to get it to work. I'd rather swish my mouth out with mouthwash than use this item!!
  290. My sister recommended this product and since I have always been happy with Panasonic products, I thought I'd give it a try......It's great and I'm very happy with it for oral hygiene.
  291. The size was perfect for traveling and it did its job; would not use for everyday as needs to be refilled in order to floss entire mouth.
  292. Based on my experience with the previous model which died days before the 2-year warranty was up, this irrigator works well. It does the job of flushing out food even after you've rinsed and brushed. But this new model arrived with the cover of the battery compartment unable to be opened. It was stuck shut. The people at Panasonic suggested I try prying it open with a screwdriver! Since its plastic, that would have demolished the cover and still left it shut.<br /><br />I just returned it to Amazon, that wonderful customer-friendly company. Amazon is sending a replacement right away. If I can get the batteries into it, I'll write a review of how well it functions.

  297. The product is useful, but not as useful as it should be. The water stream is not powerful enough to fully clean one's teeth, particularly if one has braces. I suspect the device will help maintain oral hygiene, but don't count on it being anywhere near as powerful as a plug in model, and don't count on it to remove all trapped food particles. Some reviewers have complained about the size of the water reservoir. It is true that the reservoir is limited, but this reviewer did not find this a problem; if needed one an always re-fill and continue. Battery life is better than expected. I used one set of batteries for two-weeks. For optimum performance, batteries probably should be changed more frequently, perhaps weekly. If you are traveling you might consider using rechargeable batteries and bringing the charger. Bottom line, the produce is better than nothing, but needs improvement.

When you are done using it, the tip goes in the side and you push the white, upper part down into the blue part.

  301. After maybe a year or so it doesn't work anymore. It turns on and makes noise like it's working but I'm guessing the pump is broken as even with a full tank of water nothing comes out. Before it broke I liked it well enough. This was my first water pick-like device so the pressure was satisfactory for me. A full tank doesn't last long though so you have to hurry and then refill for a more thorough cleaning.
  302. I purchased the item because I recently got braces on my teeth. I highly recommend this product, great power, and convenience.
  303. I've been using a Braun-Oral B stationary water pick since 1999 and I'm totally satisfied with it. Unfortunately it was recently broken down after so many years of service. I wanted to buy it again, but the model was discontinued, perhaps because it was so durable and they couldn't make a good sale out of it. After reading many reviews, I decided to buy this Panasonic portable water pick, keeping in mind that it has a disadvantage of being 'bulky', especially for my kids. I don't mind this, because I've already ordered a WaterPick WP100 for them, as they are now a bit more grown up and stay on a different floor in our house. The product arrived on time in a thorough packaging, though I believe the high quality of its plastic would not require such a thoroughness. Being prepared to see a bulky thing, I was not very surprised with its modest size when it was in the package. It was just 6.5 inches high. However, I admit that when I expanded it for use, I said \\"wow\\". It became ~1.5 times higher, which is 8.5 inches. I'm now sure that my 8-year-old son wouldn't love holding it in his hand. However, it should be OK for my daughter, who is only 6.3 feet height, because it is just right with me, who is not too much higher (I'm an Asian guy of medium size). What I'm surprised most with this product is that its pulsated stream of water was just of the right size and power, the same like of the Braun-Oral B I used before. The only difference is that with Braun-Oral B I had the ability to adjust the power step-less. However, I always had to watch the dial to stay at the right low and high points that I later found other family members of mine also use. With Panasonic, the water is just right for normal cleaning when I turn it on, at the first speed. At the second speed, it is also just right for clearing of more 'stubborn' debris. I can imagine how much research had the Panasonic engineers done to find out this point. Still, this is not everything. I must say that every detail of this product shows its quality and rationality. The pick is turnable so that you can adjust it at your right angle, but it sits tight enough to not rotate spontaneously. The hose inside the tank made the unit usable at any angle. The power switch and battery lid are very well water-proof. The lid of the tank is also very good. Once I rush to meetings and just throw the unit in my drawer without discharging redundant water. In the car, I realized that there were some important paper together with it, and I rushed back just to find out that nothing happened. There was no water leaking. All in one, this portable water pick is paying off for its value of money. I would recommend it not only for travel, but also for use at home. It can even replace the stationary version, because thanks to the right size of its tank, you don't have to refill it many times during one use.
  304. Easy, low tech, portable. Have used others with more complex systems and like the battery system best. Easy to carry on a trip/no outlets or cords. Also affordable to replace every few years.
  305. Great price, and very nice product. I looked into this type of product for weeks trying to decide on what to buy. Even would go out to store to see them for comparisons. This is compact and great to travel with and I like that it runs on batteries. Takes up very little space on the counter and the water chamber is not an issue for me, just add more water. So far so good and hoping my dentist will see the results.

Not sure why others are complaining about this unless they are spending a minute or two on each tooth. Probably runs for about a minute, which is enough for cover all the territory. But even if you need to reload more water, its a very simple thing to do. This is a very simple device designed to do one thing and it does it pretty well at a reasonable price. Can't ask for much more

  329. I'm afraid the 123 people who gave this contraption a 4 or 5 star review, seem to have no clue as to what a good dental irrigator is all about. The water pressure, even at the high #2 setting is pitifully low, compared to, say, a Waterpik or similar electronic type. The water reservoir is so small, it has emptied out after 30-40 seconds - meaning that for a good irrigation job, you end up refilling it four or five times. Even with water in it, you have to keep moving your wrist around to keep the water jet going properly. To top it all off, the water reservoir leaks, should you not use the irrigator right away. In other words, don't fill it up and put it down for a bit, because you meant to do something else, however briefly. The worst appliance I ever bought.

But tonight I changed the batteries, and it's still acting like it's on its last leg. I have braces. I have to use something. I suppose I will just keep buying these rip-offs until I get my braces off and that won't be for another year. Why can't someone make a good one of these?<br /><br />Since I first purchased this item, I have realized I need to check to make sure my batteries are new and work well. That makes a huge difference.<br /><br />Also, when the product starts getting dirty, I submerge the whole thing (minus the battery) in a container full of hydrogen peroxide. I leave it there for 24 hours and then am able to clean it and make sure any accumulated crud comes out of it.<br /><br />Disregard my prior remarks....this product is well worth buying (especially when you have braces)!

  361. Having used several water pic type devices, I decided to try this Panasonic portable one so I could appease my dentist. Have not actually traveled with it except to walk around the bathroom--you need a sink close by for the mouth drainage--but it is compact and could easily fit in a shaving kit. I am still on the first set of batteries--AA alkaline--after several months. The force is adjustable--2 positions, and the attacked \\"tank\\" holds enough water for one cleaning. Nice not to have an additional cord on the counter. The freedom of not having a water line, tank, and AC cord make this model more user friendly. It is easy to fill the tank--have not used with anything except water and don't feel a need to do so. Was most surprised at the unpleasant taste I occasionally find hiding between teeth even after brushing. Disgusting but...
  362. In decided on this one because there's not a lot of counter space in my bathroom. I gave away my bigger one because it took up too much room, and was a pain to deal with. This one has two speed/force settings, which is nice. The top slides down into the reservoir making it compact and easy to travel with. However, there is nothing to keep the top up, so when you're trying to use it the top slides down. Wouldn't be a horrible event, except it blocks the on/off switch. When you pull it back up the entire unit is wet, now it's slippery.
  363. This is my first \\"oral irrigator\\". I've had it for about a month and it didn't take long to get the hang of it. I think it has been useful especially when I forget to floss. I think the pressure could be harder.

The tip on the new unit is very tight and it's a struggle to get it out of the unit for packing. That is the only downside. Found this product a couple of years ago after having problems with Water-Pik rechargeable batteries not lasting more than a year. This is a much better way to go.

However, it is important to me to have an oral irrigator which does a thorough job. BTW, the tips were shipped from Goodman's and delivered in record time. Now I'm happy as a lark (how happy is a lark?) because I'm using my WaterPik and I have something that's not cumbersome to travel with.

  383. all my family love this gizmo, much better than the wire!
  384. Had this unit for 2+ years thus far.<br /><br />1) Only two speed settings - mid or high. High is too painful for me, and mid doesn't seem to have enough punch. Not really as good as the countertop Waterpik that has many settings.<br /> Tip does have room to get all the way back there.<br /><br />2) Water runs out quickly. You can expect that if you're carefully spraying in between each tooth, and along the entire gumline in and out, you may need 2-3 fillups to cover the entire mouth.<br /><br />3) Not easy at all to turn the power off with the finger/thumb while it's being used. Thus, when going from one side of the mouth to the other, or top to bottom, your gums/inner cheeks get a painful spray. Else, you'll have to take it out of your mouth and it'll jet everywhere. Or, you'll have to awkwardly hold it while you fumble for the off position, and that area of the tooth/gums get blasted a bit too long.<br /> Expect to hold your mouth open over a sink all the time or the water coming out will go everywhere - mirror, sinktop, etc.<br /><br />4) Cleaning - simply dump water out from hole, wash outside with soap and water, fill hole with a bit of clean water, spray it until empty, pull unit apart, wash with soap and water, detatch tip, wash with soap and water. Dry outside on clean towel, shake out as much water as you can from container part, set out on clean towel in dry area to air dry completely.<br /> Pretty much the only sure way to make sure the unit is DRY and CLEAN, which prevents mold/bacterial growth.<br /> If you're not happy with doing this each and every time you use the unit, this is not for you.<br /><br />5) Otherwise, for a 'portable pik', it works decent for the AA's it runs on.<br /> BUT, given the money, if I had to buy only one, I'd go back to the Waterpik countertop used for decade+ for cleaning. Just works like it should and you always have one hand free to turn the spray on/off/up/down as you need to.
  385. I purchased two of these about two months ago for my children with braces. They are very simple to use, durable, and do not at all \\"burn up batteries\\" as one reviewer had it. In fact, we have not even had to change the batteries yet! My kids fill up the irrigator about three times in order to do a thorough job. There is a big improvement in the cleanliness of their teeth as a result of using this. These irrigators are really excellent for travel as well, since they are so compact and are batter-operated. I recently bought one for myself since I was so impressed.
  386. I bought the original irrigator many years ago, and it still works. The intake tube on that model tended to get algae growing in it. The new one has dual speeds (very nice for sensitive gums) and the batteries last much longer. Other than that, the case has a different color. It looks more &#34;medical&#34;. Same if not better performance, and a nice upgrade to the original.

I find one filling of the water reservoir is sufficient for each irrigation - I don't have to refill as some reviewers have said. Although it is recommended not to use rechargeable batteries, I have done so at times, and have had no problems with this so far (4 months of daily usage). The main thing is to keep the top of the unit dry after use, so as to help reduce any moisture ingress into the battery compartment. Overall, a good buy.

  448. Flossing was never my strong point and now I'm paying for it. I bought this water flosser at the recommendation of my hygenist and I must say, it does Not suck! It really helps blast particles left behind out of my mouth. It did take some getting used to and here is what I do now:<br /><br />1. Fill the water tank with cool (not cold) water<br />2. Place the tip into my mouth, keeping my teeth together, but my lips slightly apart on one side<br />3. Lean over the sink and turn the flosser on<br />4. Trace along the gumline and inbetween teeth, letting the excess water spill from one side of my cheek<br /><br />Very pleased I got this, as it comes in really handy for dislodging dinner bits and such. Easy to use. Perfect that it is battery operated, so you don't have to deal with cords. I feel like it gives me a solid minute to two minutes of thorough flossing action.

  453. For a cheap, portable oral irrigator, you really can't beat this product. I've read where people don't feel that the reservoir doesn't hold enough water. Hello. It's portable, meaning smaller. If you want a larger water receptacle, buy the big water pick or other large unit. In the meanwhile, when the water runs out, refill it. This isn't brain surgery folks. It's water. It's probably right there in front of you...in the faucet. I usually mix some Listerine in with the water for a nice fresh result.<br />If you have hard water with minerals in it that gunk up your unit, fill a clean 2 liter soda bottle with filter water from your fridge or Brita and use that in the unit.<br />I got a couple years use from my 1st Panasonic, and then had to buy another one, but it's pretty inexpensive compared to the 'professional' unit the dentist just sold to my s/o for $140, which takes up valuable room on the sink, and which he will never use.

  579. I've used a water-pik for several years, but after getting braces on my teeth it became an absolute necessity. Enough so that when I realized I was going on a week-long trip, I didn't want to be without SOMEthing to clean out the gunk. So I grabbed this competitor from Panasonic to use for travel. It was good for a short trip, but I didn't have the smallest temptation to replace the full size water-pik with this after I returned home.<br /><br />The plus points: The Panasonic Irrigator is fairly light, and it squishes into a relatively compact size. It does an adequate cleaning job (which is the most important point!). And it runs on batteries; portability is an advantage.<br /><br />However, it doesn't have anything like the control you get from the counter-top water-pik unit. It's fast-or-slow, that's it; and \\"slow\\" is rather slow. If you have the water-pik set to a strong setting you might be disappointed with the pressure. I'm fine with this for a trip, but wouldn't be satisfied with it for the long term. Especially since you're sticking half of the apparatus in your mouth every time, and it seems like the unit has a tendency to get grotty. While a regular water-pik lets you share (I get the blue tube, you get the red one), this might be a very personal unit.<br /><br />I can comfortably given this 3.5-to-4 stars for a travel unit. But if I were judging it for daily use over the long term (in a \\"gosh is the cheaper item good enough?\\" way) I'd give it only 2 or 3 stars.
  580. hard to reach the back side of lower teeth. If you tilt it too much, the bump can't get water.

  582. I used a Water Pic (about $60.00) for a year or so and struggled with the low power/slow pulse cleaning process. Recharging the battery made little, or no difference.<br /><br />The $35.00 Panasonic unit holds more water, has a more efficient, 2-speed sprayer, and is easier to clean & dry between use, since the spray tip is very easy to remove. The non-rechargeable batteries might be only drawback for some people (but not for me). This one is 5 stars, in every respect!

  586. It pulses instead of having a continuous spray. I initially believed the spray wasn't as powerful, but I put my regular plug-in irrigator side-by-side outside and the spray distance was the same. But other people might prefer the pulse, so I can't ding it too much for that.<br /><br />It also has a tendency to smell if you disassemble it and put it up after each use. I've been washing off the wand part with soap periodically, and leaving it out on the counter more, and that takes care of it.<br /><br />Holding it is also a bit of a drawback, as holding a big thing in your hand makes cleaning out your mouth more difficult. I wish this had a base with a wand attached, but was still compact and ran on batteries.<br /><br />One advantage it has is when I drain out my regular irrigator to take on trips, it takes a while for the pump to prime and start using it. This thing starts up immediately, and even the directions recommend keeping it running until the water has completely drained after each use.<br /><br />I don't like this as much as my regular plug-in irrigator overall, but this one is much more transportable, obviously, and it works well. I'm now using this one because my regular one trips the electric outlet I'm using now, and it's much easier to transport this one around, obviously. So even though it's not perfect, I'm very glad I got it.<br /><br />UPDATE 11/20/12: I upgraded my rating to 5 stars, since I've bought one for every member of the family. And the bulkiness of it isn't a concern once you get used to it. I think I'll stay with this version in the future instead of dealing with the plug-in versions. Just be ready to switch out the batteries once they start to run down, as weaker batteries affect the performance a lot.

The good thing is that you can pull the reservoir off and clean it and its most important to let it completely dry out between use.   689. I had an older Water Pik that died. This cordless Panasonic unit works very well. The slot in the top of the battery compartment is shaped to take the edge of a quarter coin for opening and closing (not noted in the instructions). The reservoir tank is easy to fill. I found that using it on the lower speed, and with a reasonable speed in moving it along my teeth, a full reservoir is just the right amount of water to cover the front and back of both lower and upper teeth. For travel use, the nozzle can be stored in the small indented space in the side of the upper unit - it is a tight fit, but I did manage to fit it into the space. If used as directed, it should not irritate the gums. This appears to be designed for adult use. If is not clear how old a child should be to use it without adult assistance.<br /><br />I would note that my dental hygienist recommends using this type appliance to remove food particles not easily removed by flossing. She tends to disapprove of snack foods like popcorn.
  690. I purchased the product for travel. It is compact and works very well. Doesn't take up a lot of limited packing space.
  691. I love that this is so easy to get out and use, and that it is water proof. With this portable model, I can take it in the shower, so no mess, and since it's hand held, no tube to limit my movement.   696. I just received my second one of these little waterpiks, finally wore out the first one after many years of daily use. I wish i'd known about these long ago, i probably could have saved thousands in dental work. Only after I started using this did I finally realize that brushing is only a half measure (and wears your teeth - the dentist told me he saw groves from the brushing, even using soft brushes). I will get a little grisly for a moment, Being the randy old fart that I am with all the attendant problems of such, I started using the waterpik because I had a pocket in the gums - that was storing food like a chipmunk in the fall, and not getting removed by brushing, the food was DECAYING (Ugh) and causing pain! But three dentists I saw for this, would not tell me the gum pocket was the problem was (although they were quite happy to let me fill their pockets, one periodontist charged me $1000 for essentially doing nothing.) This inexpensive contraption fixed up that issue perfectly. When you can see the debris (food - yuk) that gets blown out of your teeth, I knew that brushing/flossing wasn't getting the teeth clean enough. Anyway, I give this product 5 stars because its cheap, it works well and it lasts a ridiculously long time. The only problem will be supplying it with batteries (I just ignore what the manual says on rechargables and use eneloops to keep the battery costs down). And I sure wish i'd starting using this product when i was a kid - if you don't use a waterpik, you might not be getting your teeth as clean as they could be.using this years ago, do yourslef a big favor - buy one before they quit making them!!!

  710. This is a nice device, is seems to work well and assists me in getting food particles out of some difficult places with minimal trauma (flossing). I'd recommend it. The only problem noted is the on and off switch...its not at all easy to move with wet hands...which they are sure to be. I think they could fix that with a minor redesign.
  711. I bought this in hopes of finding the lazy way out of flossing. It's not because I hate flossing that much, just more that I had braces in my mouth and flossing with braces is beyond frustrating and time-consuming. I used it, and it seemed to do the trick pretty well until I went back to the orthodontist and discovered this irragator wasn't as thorough as I was hoping it would be. There was still some plaque buildup on my teeth. It wasn't until after I removed my braces that I realized it didn't irrigate out everything. So yeah, it'll catch the stuff it can reach, but it can't get to all of it. I am also running into the issue of it being sanitary. I leave the cap open and don't compact it so the water doesn't stagnate, but I'm trying to figure out the best way to sanitize it so it doesn't leave any residual or mold or what have you. As far as water pressure, on a new battery it's great, but once it wears down the water stream becomes noticeably weaker. Overall, I'd say buy it if you need to use it in lieu of flossing, but flossing is probably still best.
  712. This device works well but if it is used frequently the batteries need changing often. It is an adequate alternative to flossing.

  726. [[VIDEOID:73951fd98d4a2e986e372e3e3f673f46]] This item is very elegant, Panasonic is a very trustworthy company from my previous experience. It is my first time making video review, please bear with me if my skills were not good. Leave a comment if you have a question about it that maybe I can help, and like it if you find it useful! I wish it could be more clear but the file size has to be under 100 MB. There are several pros and cons. Pros. 1. It is very strong, the battery that came with it is manufactured by Panasonic as well, it is disposable battery, and the manual recommends no rechargeable battery. 2. The level 2 is even stronger than level 10 in the corded water flosser \\"Waterpik WP-660 Aquarius Professional Water Flosser\\". I bought that for my mom, and I feel that is not as powerful as this one. 3. It removes all the things between your teeth perfectly. 4. Portable and looks very elegant, and can be carry everywhere, it can be smaller too by inserting the irrigator into the tank. 5. Consider this as an investment, it saves money compared to using the regular flosser. Still, the battery is an expense as well. Cons. 1. The top where you insert battery is hard to open and close for the first time users. But it is understandable because it helps to prevent water from flowing in. 2. The tank cannot be detached from the irrigator, and the tank only has a little hole where you put water. This means it is hard to wipe the water inside using a paper. This can be problematic because if water is there for a period of time and you did not remove it, there can be mold as mentioned by other reviewers. 3. It only comes with one pick. The corded waterpik had all different types of pick for different use. 4. The tank is small and not enough for a thorough mouth clean. I will put more updates if people find this helpful. Again, bear with me for my inexperience in making video review, I have to hold it one-handed.

  735. I bought this intending to use rechargeable AAs with it, but the instruction booklet says not to because of possible corrosion. This was a disappointment for me and I may try rechargeables anyway.<br /><br />Low speed is a nice option for dispensing ACT or other mouthwash to the gum line, but the reservoir is so small that you must work very quickly - note the instructions suggest to use only water and to always empty the unit after use). The on/off switch is extremely stiff though. Note that on high speed it is much less powerful than a standard Waterpick but still effective. This might be a good thing if you're concerned about damage from the higher pressure Waterpick. Pulsing water pressure can dislodge restorations, mind you!<br />=====<br />(Reporting back in 2013) I used rechargeables now for some time in this without issue other than their very tight fit. They should work just fine for you too if you can make them fit. Respect the earth.<br /><br />The soft battery cover can easily be damaged by the wrong tool to open it (a quarter did this in my case). I found though that a 5-cent nickle does the job nicely without damage. I keep one with the unit ready for battery changes.<br /><br />Because of the tiny reservoir though, I find I just don't use it (I can't get through my whole mouth without refilling it).
  736. This is the first portable I've used, and I was very disappointed in both the size of the tank (could not get more than one side done per tankful) and the force of the water.
