  738. Nov 6, 2012 Update:<br />I reduce my rating to 3 stars because I discovered and bought a Redi-Breeze irrigator (from Amazon) that fastens to the faucet, that does a better job, not requiring battery changes, not subject to performance fall-off as the batteries decline, nor filling a reservoir or cleaning the unit. It's just a better system. Its location on Amazon follows: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0028OV2S0/ref=oh_details. However, I will take the portable Panasonic unit with me when traveling.<br /><br />Update a year later, April 3, 2012:<br />I still rate this 5 stars, and am still using it. I haven't kept a record exactly how long batteries last, maybe 2 months, but when I change them, I take it apart, clean it and let it dry overnight. It still works like new, and I use it three times a day.<br /><br />Original Review: For years I have thought that a portable water pick would be a good idea, but never thought until recently to see if one existed. The reviews for this Panasonic unit were better than others for sale, and I ordered it for that reason. Coincidentally, my plug-in unit failed a day or so after the Panasonic arrived, so I use it several times a day, plus on a recent overnight motorcycle trip to Big Bear Lake, CA. The jet pulse stream is actually stronger than that of my former plug-in, and it has continued to operate strongly on the first set of (2 AA) batteries for about a month. The reservoir capacity is perfect for one usage. It folds up very well to pack for a trip, with the jet piece easily removed and stored safely in the unit. A couple of days ago I looked for a replacement plug-in at Walmart. I found them all to be quite expensive, so I decided to continue to use the Panasonic portable all the time.

  754. This is an excellent product. It replaces a WaterPic which replaced a WaterPic . . . Using regular batteries on this Panasonic Oral Irrigator causes the action to last much much longer and with more power than the WaterPic's rechargeable batteries and there are fewer breakable parts. Our last WaterPic has the water refill opening on top, so when someone used the pick, their &#34;mouth backwash&#34; accumulated around the opening, some of it under the cover so it wasn't noticed until the cover was open again ... ick! Did I say ick? I meant ICK. This device is marvelous. The water compartment can be removed from the generator and in this state, it can be completely washed AND dried, something you can't do when only a small hole is available for filling and draining. More amazing, it can be collapsed for packing. I am very satisfied with it, especially in comparison with a competing product. Note that I drain the water compartment after use and leave its plug open so the compartment can dry out as I believe it is more sanitary.

  760. My dental hygenist was not terribly happy when I told her that I don't floss. She also wasn't super happy to hear I was using a water pik type cleaner either. She said she was worried about the force of the water. I guess if you aim it wrong, you could do some damage to your periodontal pockets (?), but I think that would hurt, so probably doesn't happen too much. Just follow the instructions and aim the water jet at 90 degrees (or slightly towards the top) to your teeth, never forcing water into your gums and you should never have a problem.<br /><br />I can't floss easily. I have several bridges that make it very hard to get the floss in. I'd have to thread the floss with a threader loop several times, and frankly, I'm not that ambitious and I don't like the feel of string in my mouth. So what I do is just leave this on the counter and use it once a week or two, and every time I use it, it gets some stuff out from under my bridges, etc. and my mouth feels nice and clean. My dental hygenist was also impressed, and said I wouldn't really benefit from flossing extra. I do brush them well every day, which I'm sure also helps.<br /><br />Let's face it, no tool will make cleaning your teeth and gums fun, but this one makes it very little work.

I recommend leaving the water cap open after use to air out. The only drawback is the on/off button which is not very tactile especially when your hands are wet and I often have to use a washcloth to turn it on/off because my fingers are sliding all over it. Howver, this is a portable unit and I am using it as my main unit. Glad I bought it and we will wait for my next periodontal appointment is 3 months to see if there is an improvement.

The thing I like the most is that the reservoir and the motor section come apart so that it can be completely dried out prior to storing. The Waterpik unit I had did not and I have given it away. I am satisfied with it.
  812. Wasn't as powerful as I thought it would be, but does a decent job conveniently. Would have been better if it was slightly cheaper though.
  813. I decided to try this irrigator after reading all the reviews on all of the irrigators available. It is very easy to set up, and the irrigator tip is easy to insert. There is a small cap that opens up the chamber to fill with water and/or mouthwash. The first time I used this irrigator, I had fluid all over the sink and counter because I was not used to using it. Over time, I finally adapted and was able to contain the fluid to the sink. There are two speeds you can use. The switch is easy to maneuver- slow, high, and off. The tip easily rotates depending on what area of the mouth you are irrigating. After using this for two weeks, I still cannot irrigate my mouth on one chamber-full of fluid because I am too slow. I am sure over time I will become faster and more accurate. I really like the way my mouth feels after using this irrigator. I am glad I purchased it. By the way, it is easy to disassemble to clean every so often.
  814. Overall, this product functions well, which just matches my expectation when I bought it only for $18.
  815. Bought this to take the &#34;waterpiking show&#34; on the road. Wish it held more fluid in the chamber but it does the job well.
  816. The feature is that it collapses for storage, so would be a good travel unit. It also runs on batteries, so no electric outlet is needed. Good for camping, etc.<br /><br />The bad part is that it is a poor choice for home use. The two AA batteries are just do not provide enough power to provide a forceful jet stream, probably about a tenth of the force of an AC WaterPic.<br /><br />In short, it's useable, but a poor replacement for an AC unit for home use. Not bad for travel, and about the only choice for camping or hiking.
  817. I was a little skeptical at first after reading some of the reviews-- someone had said the button was too hard to move and they had problems turning it off. I would say my device is the exact opposite and I accidentally sprayed myself in the face, and have sprayed my bathroom mirror more than once. I saw other people complaining theirs showed up broken, they didn't work for whatever reason, etc. My irrigator has been great and other than accidentally spraying myself a couple of times, it's been great.<br /><br />I really like how clean everything feels after I use this. I brush my teeth with a panasonic electric toothbrush every morning and night, and I follow up brushing with alcohol-free listerine. I added the irrigator to my nightly routine, I use it on the first setting (which is still a little painful).<br /><br />Originally, I wanted something to help clean around my wisdom teeth. I still have all of them and cleaning can be really difficult at times. I use floss picks throughout the day, but they still had a tendency to be a source of bad breath for me. It's not really an issue anymore since I began using this! My boyfriend also uses it to clean tonsil pockets (though he did say it was a little painful) but it works really well.
  818. Good size for traveling; good water pressure; good tank size - just enough water if I hurry. I like this dental irrigator for traveling. Update August 26, 2014. I bought this same dental irrigator in 2009 and it worked fine. The next year no water could be pumped. I thought that was a fluke, so I bought this dental irrigator again in 2013. Again, one year later, in 2014, it wouldn't pump water. My review was changed from 5 stars (for short-term use) to 1 star (for long-term use). Unfortunately a lot of people won't read this review, but if you do, please keep looking for another irrigator unless you are willing to buy this one for only short-term use. I bought two of these, four years apart, and I had to throw both of them away.
  819. I have had Braun and Waterpik oral irrigators over the years and this little beauty is the best of all. No unreliable rechargeable batteries needed or cords so you can use it anywhere in the world on 2 AA batteries. The flow is surprisingly strong and it collapses for easy storage. You don't know what clean teeth are until you have tried this. It is far more effective than floss and cheaper in the long term. You know how effective it is when you use it between your back molars and can smell the bacteria as they are cleansed out - disgusting but very reassuring - better out than in!

  846. I just got this today, and I'm using it with NiMH AA batteries. I tested it and it worked fine with them.<br /><br />I'm not OK with using devices that require disposable batteries when they could be powered by rechargeable batteries. The fact that the batteries are just driving a small motor using a good bit of current made this product a good candidate for MiMH batteries. The reason given in the instructions for not using rechargeable batteries - corrosion - doesn't make sense.<br /><br />I'll be using this regularly - several times a day - and I will report back if I have any problems with it or with using it with rechargeable batteries. I expect to get better battery life with the NMH batteries, to save a good bit of money by using them, and to avoid polluting the environment with used alkaline batteries.<br /><br />Update after 2 months of use:<br /><br />I've recharged the batteries twice. The unit is still working very well. I recharge the batteries when I notice a significant slow down and reduction in pressure.

  852. The new Panasonic irrigator has a battery compartment and electrodes similar to the previous model (EW1270AC), so I'm sure the same comments apply:<br /><br />My old irrigator gave out after 5 years of travel-only use. It occasionally wouldn't switch on, finally wouldn't switch on at all. Batteries were good. I scraped the (-) contact in the battery compartment cap and the (+) contact at the bottom of the battery compartment with a straightened-out wire coat hanger and it worked again.<br /><br />These contacts do corrode. If you're not going to use the device for a while, take the batteries out and leave the battery compartment cap off for a few days to let the contacts dry thoroughly.<br /><br />This Panny supplies higher water pressure than the old model but not as much as my WaterPik (WP100) and I wouldn't rely on it for daily use. However, it's great for travel. Note the WaterPik cordless models (WP360, WP450) have a 110-120 vac charger rating rather than the 110-240 vac that all my other plug-in portable devices have, so the WaterPik can't be used in Europe with a plug adapter; you'd need a (heavy and bulky) step-down transformer.<br /><br />And I wouldn't use any dental irrigator as a substitute for daily flossing.

The trouble is you have to keep your lips almost shut and do the whole cleaning by feel only. The other problem is one container of water is not enough for me and it is annoying to have to refill it.   950. This is a tremendous value. The marketplace has so many expensive, high-end models to choose from that this product doesn't garner the attention it deserves. It does an excellent job blasting away debris between my teeth, offers two pressure settings for those with and without sensitive gums, and is small enough to be bring on over-nights and vacations. The small compartment that houses the nozzle when collapsed and not in use is a clever idea that will ensure it never goes missing. I also enjoy that it's battery operated. I always have spare batteries on me (either in my house or car), so there won't be any cases of poor timing when I want to use it but it's not charged. And although it warns against the use of any liquid besides water, I prefer to mix a cap-full or two of mouthwash in as well for additional advantages.<br /><br />The one inherent drawback is the bulkiness of the device in your hand. Because the tank is hosted within the handheld, it will take a few uses before becoming accustomed to holding it comfortably and learning how to best maneuver it.<br /><br />I read many positive reviews of this product before I purchased and it met all of my expectations. I highly recommend this tool for everyone trying to take better care of their teeth and gums, but especially for those unwilling or unable to invest in the less cost-effective alternatives.

I use this in addition to flossing and find that it gets to the back teeth better than you ever could manually. It may take your gums some getting used to but after a couple of weeks of consistent use I find it to be strong without being painful and I have sensitive gums. It doesn't cause any irritation or bleeding and also leaves your breath fresher for longer. A word of caution though, don't stand the same way you would while brushing your teeth. The splash is amazing. The first time I used it it ended up all over my mirror and the walls. It wasn't one of my brightest moments. If you lean forward over the sink and cup your hand over the top of your mouth you can use it easily and quickly if you don't have the time or desire to use it while showering. I am definitely pleased with this and would purchase another should anything ever happen to this one.

  997. 9/5/14 just took it out of the box. In it's closed up mode it reminds me of the size of those slender &#34;ENERGY DRINKS&#34; cans.<br />I'm reviewing from a mature woman's perspective. Then to put the batteries in place you need something with width because you need to turn this nickle size white plastic screw on top to the word &#34;open&#34;. After using several women &#34;thingamagigs&#34; I went and got hubby's flat head screw driver and 1 stern twist and we have lift off. I inserted the batteries and replaced the screw thingy.<br />Went to the kitchen sink area to test out my &#34;dentistry&#34; skills. FILLING was a matter of flipping open the tab, (you'll see it) and running<br />some water into it...I used luke water as suggested, so as not to have a first time shock. It takes 3 seconds of water intake to fill it, hence the 40 SECONDS OF RUN TIME. So i proceeded to test out my &#34;dentistry skills&#34;. Well it wasn't in my mouth all the way or a good angle, and my left ear got a nice irrigation. (TIP: HAVE TOWELS HANDY and HAIR IN TURBAN). The reviews asking about the noise is meaningless as it only runs for 40 Seconds. By the time I was done with 3 refills to work on techniques, my ear, hair on left side, and kitchen cabinets needed a wipe down.   1020. The oral irrigator has very good water pressure and less bulky than others I've seen, it's compact and great for travel.
  1021. The directions say don't use rechargeable batteries, and they mean it. Rechargeable NiMH (Nickel metal hydride) batteries put out 1.2 volts per cell, compared to 1.5 volts for alkaline throwaways. With the rechargeables, the irrigator does pump water, but it's too weak to do much good. I'm getting about 15 to 20 uses out of a set of throwaways. At that point, the irrigator is still working but getting pretty weak. (The batteries still have enough juice to power a LED flashlight.) I think Panasonic could add a voltage regulator circuit that would enable you to use rechargeables and would extend the life of throwaways. That would increase the price, no doubt.<br /><br />Aside from the need to use throwaway batteries, I'm satisfied with this item.
  1022. I needed a waterpic under the recommendation of my dentist. I order the Panasonic, because it was battery operated. I had read horror stories about the rechargable batteries not working afer a couple of months on other units. This product works great. It is compact and is very easy to operate.   1028. I previously purchased a waterpik rechargeable version of this product and after about 3-4 months the battery stopped holding a charge. This model seems much better built, becomes compact for traveling (even protecting the tip) and runs on rechargeable or alkaline batteries, which can be purchased anywhere. For a travel product, Panasonic seems to have hit a sweet spot. Should this one die, I won't think twice about buying it again-there just isn't any competition at this time. If you want it for home only, you might be better with something you plug in; for travel/home use, don't bother trying anything else.<br /><br />Update<br />Despite the instructions saying not to use rechargeable batteries, I've been using quality NiMH (eneloops) for a week with no appreciable loss of power. While they don't have the initial \\"oomph\\" of alkaline's, after about 4 uses, the alkaline loses its advantage and runs at the same level of the NiMH. So I will continue using my eneloops. I would caution you though, they didn't last long with my energizer rechargeables.
  1029. I like this product - it does what it's supposed to, as long as you have fresh batteries in it. I tried rechargeables, but they weren't powerful enough.   1042. I researched air & water-based electronic flossers, because I recently attained orthodontic braces. I finally decided on this one & I am quite pleased. It provides strong bursts of water into hard-to-reach spots, & I haven't had any problems with gum irritation. However, regular dental floss is still necessary, because it doesn't remove the plaque that has built up throughout the day, when I use this after brushing. Nevertheless, it's convenient, the tank is the appropriate size to use on my entire mouth without refilling. I prefer using it while in the shower, because it can get messy since the water is spraying at a moderately quick and powerful level. I have only had it few weeks, so I can't comment on battery life, but as mentioned, I've been impressed with the power of the stream, so I won't be too surprised if the batteries don't last a long time. Overall, pleased with the purchase, and even my husband who doesn't have braces has started using it, because it is quite refreshing. Love to add a little mouthwash to the water, but I may find that clogs the scope in the future as well.
  1043. I was very surprised how well I liked this, it is strong, but not too strong! It got stuff out of my gums and I think my dentist will be pleased. It is definitely a learning curve sprayed the bathroom mirror first time, and I don't think it is a sharable item, we will be ordering another one.
  1044. This irrigator is great at removing particles from between my teeth. Flossing hurts and often misses food. The irrigator gets everything...even when I think there is nothing to get!<br /><br />My gums feel massaged every time I use it! Rather than feeling assaulted like they do when I floss, the irrigator makes my gums feel good. I'm due for a dental appointment, I'm interested to see the results.
  1045. Bought this to replace my very old and dirty Waterpik. I choose this Panasonic model because it has less footprint compared to the Waterpik, very portable and costs less than the other portable brands. It works great with a full charge but gets weak about near the second or third week of use (I use it once a day) Contrary to what the instructions tell you, I use a rechargeable battery and I find that this one is the only one that works for the unit: Duracell rechargeable preCharged AA/HR6/DX 1500 NiMH 1,2V /2000 mAh . I have another rechargeable Duracell battery but it does not work on it. I use it while in the shower but not directly under the spray, but I am sure it's water proof. Be sure to clean the tank regularly too.
  1046. catches dirt very easily. Need to clean it everyday.
  1047. i'm very happy with it, is a very good one. is powerful and nice to handle it help me to keep tooth clean and shine
  1048. After reading a number of reviews for oral irrigators, I settled on this Panasonic one. Now, I have nothing to compare it to, but I love it! I have had it for a year and it is working just fine. I have rarely gone a night without using it because it leaves my mouth feeling so refreshed.<br /> There are two speeds and after a few days I think most people will only use the higher one. It is made just for water, and though I have read that others add mouthwash to it, I have been satisfied using just water and swishing with mouthwash separately.<br /> The only downside is the battery life. It requires two AA batteries which work at their maximum potential for about two weeks. After that, you get medium potential for a while. But, I do like the product well enough to put up with it.
  1049. Great product. Does exactly what I wanted it to do.
  1050. battery not rechargable..and only has good power with fresh batteries..otherwise i like it alot.
  1051. this is awesome. I have a lot of problems with my teeth and was going on a trip to Europe and wanted something that was battery operated as we had enough things to plug in with computers, phones and cameras.
  1052. I just received this recently. Purchased it for an upcoming trip. Did a trial run with it the other day and it works great! There is plenty of pressure on the #1 speed for me. Doubt I'd ever need to go the the second. Noticed complaints that it doesn't hold enough water for some people. I do not find this to be a problem as I use a proxy brush, then floss, then use the water flosser so I only need a small amount of water to do the trick. In my opinion, if they made the unit to hold more water, it would become too large for travel. Think I'll enjoy this a lot when I travel. It's exactly what I was looking for.
  1053. Easy to fill, I use it in the shower. Maybe not quite as powerful as a corded if the batteries aren't new and I wish it came with two heads. However for the price I paid on a gold box deal, I am happy with the purchase.
  1054. Very nice unit. My only complaint is that the water runs out so quick...but it is, afterall, a travel Irrigator, so I kept 5 stars
  1055. I like the idea of a portable water irrigator versus the countertop model. I also tried a shower model (you add it to your shower head and divert water to the irrigator--leaks unless you are a whiz with teflon tape. I'm not. And then I had to install a thing to mount it on the shower stall wall. Eh, too much trouble.)<br /><br />This is just what I wanted. You load two Double-A batteries in the compartment underneath (opens with a coin.) You fill the blue part with lukewarm water by opening a little hinged door and simply running tap water into it. Then you put the nozzle in your mouth (first, lest you want to squirt up the mirror) and turn it on. Aim the nozzle around your gums and go. Very pleasant. There are two settings, low and high. Ultimately as you get used to the pressure, you'll use high. It isn't as strong as the countertop models unless you aim the stream directly into the gumline. But I was able to use the highest pressure immediately (maybe because I floss and use an electric brush.) It feels great and it gets the gunk out between your teeth and gums. Now, I'm wondering if there is a purse case for it, because I'd like to have it with me after lunch. I hate having food stuck in my teeth after I eat and you know, when you're dealing with the public, spinach on your teeth is a no-go.<br /><br />Highly recommended for convenience. Could have come with a spare tip, I think. A minor quibble.
  1056. I love it. My teeth feel so clean.
  1057. Works as advertised. Compact and effective.
  1058. This worked well for the first couple months, but then it started leaking out the side during use. Also, there was some odd suction action with the tank during use that would force the tank up as the water emptied, which forced the water to leak even more.
  1059. Very slight difference from old model.. I have usedPanasonic for twenty or so years. It used every day. Much better than any others on the market. If I don't use it every day, gums start to give trouble.
  1060. I love it! It's great for travel. It is not as powerful as a larger model but works very well.
  1061. I purchased the Panasonic Oral Irrigator for my son who has a small bathroom and does not have enough room for the Waterpik brand. The Panasonic is very compact - the perfect size for a small bathroom or traveling. I have tried it a couple of times and am quite impressed. Ordinarily, I use the Waterpik which I really like. However, in comparison, I find the Panasonic Oral Irrigator to offer the same water irrigation speed as the WaterPik and to be equally effective with mouth/teeth irrigation. While I did read one review that described the awkwardness of having to hold the entire Panasonic unit to use it, I did not find this to be true. Actually, the stationary nozzle on the Panasonic is more flexible than my Waterpik nozzle with the hose, which is prone to curling and thus, difficult to maneuver. You do have to make sure the Panasonic nozzle is in your mouth before you turn it on because it does not have a control switch like the WaterPik. I like this Panasonic product and have already ordered a second one for my travels.
  1062. For my home use this is a great product. It is small it holds plenty of water for 1 bath and it folds up to be even smaller. It irrigates well. Also great for traveling.

If you like it strong as in number 10 on your plug in water pik, then this is more like number 4 at the most. It is definitely better than not using one at all, but only if portable is all you can find room for; as in traveling and living out of a suitcase.

  1087. For close on seven years, since I had dental implants inserted, which support both upper and lower arches of teeth, I have been using the Braun/Oral B brush and irrigator system. I seldom used the brush attachment, preferring a manual brush. When the water pressure side of the system ceased to perform satisfactorily, I bought the Waterpik, which I have reviewed in that section. There was no portable version of an irrigator available in Australia so - when travelling - I relied on a needle-less syringe to remove particles from under the bridges - a somewhat tedious exercise, as you might imagine, and only partially satisfactory. (I do, of course use super-floss to clean implant posts and under bridges)<br />It was while perusing Amazon for the Waterpik that I came across this little gem.The Panasonic irrigator seems the perfect travel-mate.<br /><br />Pros - It's compact, light, and easily packable.<br /> Strong jet<br /> Top section stores in the water tank, along with the jet<br /> Comfortable to hold when using<br /><br />Cons - As a previous view pointed out, the water cannot be completely emptied from the tank when packing.<br /> Although the tank appears clear of water, it should be placed in a sealed plastic bag when packing for<br /> travelling - not really a huge problem!<br /><br />Other have commented on the difficulty of filling the tank - Personally, I don't find it a problem.<br />A tank full of water doesn't last for long but hey! The unit is meant for travelling and for that, it's perfect.<br />There have been complaints about the unit failing after a short period of time and parts breaking; my unit is very new, but - if it lasts a reasonable length of time, I'll just replace it - the unit isn't covered by warranty in Australia and it's cheap enough!<br />In fact, providing it hasn't broken down by the time I return from a forthcoming trip,(and because my bathroom bench space is limited)I'll be storing my Waterpik for use if the Panasonic does break down and while waiting for a replacement!

I purchased the extra tips, but don't actually know why I would need them unless I were sharing the use of the Flosser with another person. The batteries that came with the item worked well for 2 months and resulted in softer water pressure that helps you get used to it. The new batteries resulted in much stronger water pressure and I am using the first and second setting--which is fine. You know the batteries are drained when the water force becomes weak at the third setting. I estimate the new batters should last at least three - four months.

  1127. I bought this to replace one of the two EW 176 models I have had for a number of years. The newer design is sleeker and doesn't have a cap on top that only trapped water and invited mold. But, like so many other things, it has been supersized: the new model is much bulkier than the old one. It is ovoid rather than round like its predecessor and I find it much harder to hold onto and just too big for something I want to tuck into my carry on bag. (The photo in the ad is misleading because it shows it on end, and you don't realize that if you rotated it it would be nearly twice as wide.) When you are talking portable, size matters, and bigger isn't better. The older model was made in Japan, and this is a Chinese product.<br /><br />Update May 2014: Now that I have had this for about 6 months, I really hate it. Its little door falls off and is hard to put back on. It's hard to collapse and hard to open fully. It is not ergonomic, not made for the human hand, and every time I try to rotate it, to turn it off without spritzing my face, I wonder if they tested it on any fairly small people, or just gorillas. I'm going to Europe this summer and no way will I bring this clunker with me.

Arrived on time, well packed but I was unable to remove to battery cover and I did not want to damage the product by forcing open the battery cover so I returned it immediately. Apparently the unit is so waterproof that you can not access the battery compartment.
  1145. I bought this in hopes of replacing a larger countertop unit that takes up a lot of space in my tiny bathroom. Was a bit disappointed with the power supplied. It is not as strong as my other unit on the lowest setting. I know it is supposed to be gentler on the gums to use these units at a lower pressure, but this seemed really too low for me and I could not get used to the change. Obviously, it does not hold much water either, but I figured if I had a unit I could actually put away after each use, it would be worth refilling it once or twice if necessary.<br /><br />Unfortunately, I have been so bummed about it's low pressure output that it is in the cabinet more permanently. I decided to keep it anyway and will still use it for traveling though.
  1146. I delayed writitng my review on this product as I wanted to see how it performs. I bought this mainly because I have implants. After more than 5 months of almost daily use, I feel my mouth and teeth are actually cleaner. I say this because after brushing and gargling, I thought all remaining food had been removed. But when I use the flosser, there are still food debris that are removed every time.<br />The manual stated not to use rechargeable. Well, since I bought it, I had been using rechargeable batteries and have had no problem with it up to this time.<br />One thing about this product though is that you have to get use to holding a larger flosser compared to a flosser where the water container is separate from the handle. I am use to it now though.<br />I recommend this for those who have implants and travel a lot as it is very portable.
  1147. My 9 year old has an expander. Tis is a very useful tool to keep it clean and is easy for her to use. We also like that its battery operated so we can take it with us wherever we go!

  1154. I got this after trying &#34;Professional Rechargeable Oral Irrigator with High Capacity Water Tank by ToiletTree Products&#34;.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. It's innovative design which occupies less space.<br />2. It's thin steam of water jet with pulsating action removes all food particles from narrow gaps between the teeth.<br />3. Two AA battery operated means it's handy to take anywhere with you.<br />4. Water Proof.<br /><br />Neutral:<br />1. Sharp edges of the plastic parts may hurt if your hands are sensitive.<br />2. Switch should have been softer to control the jet pressure.<br />3. Water filling hole should have been at the top of bottom tank so that, even if the lid damaged, you can still use the unit.<br /><br />Overall it's the best for it's price and features.
  1155. I could not get the battery compartment open and the instructions did not help a bit. Finally a neighbor managed to overcome the obstacle.
  1156. After years of neglect I have been diagnosed with gum disease. I had a root scaling and planing and continued with my bad habits thinking that the problem will disappear. Later I was told I should have gum flap surgery. All four quarters. Scheduled the very next week. 12mm pockets. $5,000. Awesome!<br /><br />So I went home and started researching the disease and treatment options. As a result I canceled that idiotic surgery, decided to drastically change my oral hygiene, had another root scaling and planing, and made an appointment for a LANAP procedure. My routine included now brushing (with a [[ASIN:B0013TVEWA Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush]], every time with a different all-natural fluoride-free toothpaste - I've tried several brands and settled on 5-6 of them), flossing, using [[ASIN:B005LF0QZI Doctor's Brushpicks, 275 Count (Pack of 4)]], chewing xylitol gum (again, tried several brand and settled on Epic (like this one but I buy in bulk from their website - [[ASIN:B006609MBG Epic Dental 100% Xylitol Sweetened Gum, Peppermint, 12 Count (Pack of 12)]]), replacing all sugar with xylitol, etc. etc. and of course using an oral irrigator.<br /><br />I bought the [[ASIN:B000GLRREU Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser]] initially. And when it broke I bought another one. And when I had to travel I realized I have to get something more portable. So I found this Panasonic irrigator. And it shortly became my main irrigator, as the Waterpik collects dust somewhere in a closet.<br /><br />This is a great unit. I have had it for 3 years now, and it still works perfectly. It works for a very long time (3-4 weeks) with one set of batteries - I use it with Eneloops. It becomes very compact when collapsed, so it is great for traveling. It is very maneuverable, much more that the Waterpik (limited by the hose lenght and rigidness). It is very easy to clean, as it comes apart very easily, and it has a very short water circuit (with the Waterpik I would always run it for a few seconds before using it because there was stale and stinky water inside the system - oh, the junk that took out of the Waterpik once!!! imagine that inside your mouth!!!). The reservoir is good size - could be a little bigger but it would defeat the portability purpose, so it's not bad - just fill it once more! It has 2 power settings, and the water pressure is adequate, not only for a battery operated unit, but for a water flosser in general. Some people complain that the Waterpik (which is more powerful than this one) is not powerful enough. Well, unless you are trying to unglue your gums or dislocate your teeth or clean your bathroom with it, this is more than enough. I am a firm believer that the irrigator has to be used in conjunction with other means of oral hygiene, and not replace them entirely. So I floss, use the brushpicks and the irrigator (very often with a distilled water / hydrogen peroxide mix).<br /><br />Most of the above I used religiously after every single meal. I became almost obsessed with the hygiene to the point that I would avoid snacking if I knew I couldn't clean my teeth afterwards. But it all paid off! Within a few months I went for my LANAP evaluation and was told that there is no need for a full scale procedure anymore, only localized for one single deep pocket. Imagine that! Now it's 3 years later and I am free of any gum disease, and all my pockets are 3mm now. I still continue to employ most of the above techniques, and this Panasonic is an integral part of it.<br /><br />All in all, this is a highly recommended item!it for a few seconds before using it because there was stale and stinky water inside the system - oh, the junk that took out of the Waterpik once!!! imagine that inside your mouth!!!). The reservoir is good size - could be a little bigger but it would defeat the portability purpose, so it's not bad - just fill it once more! It has 2 power settings, and the water pressure is adequate, not only for a battery operated unit, but for a water flosser in general. Some people complain that the Waterpik (which is more powerful than this one) is not powerful enough. Well, unless you are trying to unglue your gums or dislocate your teeth or clean your bathroom with it, this is more than enough. I am a firm believer that the irrigator has to be used in conjunction with other means of oral hygiene, and not replace them entirely. So I floss, use the brushpicks and the irrigator (very often with a distilled water / hydrogen peroxide mix).<br /><br />Most of the above I used religiously after every single meal. I became almost obsessed with the hygiene to the point that I would avoid snacking if I knew I couldn't clean my teeth afterwards. But it all paid off! Within a few months I went for my LANAP evaluation and was told that there is no need for a full scale procedure anymore, only localized for one single deep pocket. Imagine that! Now it's 3 years later and I am free of any gum disease, and all my pockets are 3mm now. I still continue to employ most of the above techniques, and this Panasonic is an integral part of it.<br /><br />All in all, this is a highly recommended item!

  1163. The Panasonic EW-DJ10 is a great product. Advantages: compact, powerful water-jet action, holds plenty of water to enable complete rapid flossing (without having to refill reservoir). The Waterpik is better as a home model (but not by much), and it, of course, holds a lot more water than any portable.<br /><br />I didn't like having to use string floss during travel (the water-floss tools are so much better), so I was looking into a portable-type water flosser. The Waterpik Waterflosser is top notch as a plug-in model-- but too bulky for travel. The Panasonic -- while not yielding quite as powerful a waterjet as the plug-in Waterpik -- does a very good job. If you like the Waterpik Waterflosser, you will likely consider the Panasonic portable as a good temporary alternative. I shied away from the portable Waterpik waterflosser, because of its many bad reviews. And, it's bulkier and more expensive than the Panasonic portable. For those people who are considering the Panasonic portable as their day-to-day at-home waterflosser -- it's good. But I would recommend the more powerful plug-in flossers for day-to day. However, I would recommend this portable flosser over the Interplak (Conair) plug-in water flossers any day. That product does not hold a candle to the Panasonic portable or to the Waterpik Waterflosser.

  1206. Works amazing for those wearing braces.
  1207. Probably the most major problem braces wearers have is tiny food bits getting stuck in your teeth that just swishing can't dislodge. If you just brush without rinsing, the brush has a tendency to simply re-deposit food on the brackets. While at home a countertop WaterPik-like device works great to solve this problem, the portable WaterPik-brand irrigators are simply huge. This Panasonic irrigator is sturdy, compact when not in use, has a generous resevoir, and it has no nooks and crannies for gunk to get stuck in. The resevoir is just big enough to rinse off the brackets on both arches. As a bonus, the tip stores in a little channel on the side so you don't lose or break it. It runs on a pair of AA's, and if the lack of a built-in rechargable battery bothers you, you can just get a pair of rechargable batteries and a charger for ten bucks or less at any drugstore. (Make sure you get the kind that don't self-discharge; they'll be marked as \\"pre-charged\\" on the shelf.) Personally I like the fact it runs on AA's; it means that if I'm out and about and the batteries are dead, I can use batteries available anywhere to get it going again. I have one of these at my desk at work and another that goes around in the car with me wherever I go. Well worth the cost.
  1208. This is a great product!We use the whole family.This is a great product at a great price!!!Using the bathroom is the most good, as there is water splashing.
  1209. I really like this tool. It is nice and compact for travel, and holds enough water for my whole mouth, when used on the lowest setting. I find the highest pressure to be a bit much, and the lowest pressure to be perfect! I bought rechargeable batteries for it too.
  1210. I use this product every day even though it is meant for travel. It has a lot of power for getting food out between your teeth. It is easy to store, easy to use, and a comfortable size. It uses batteries but they do not wear out fast. I love it.
  1211. I purchased one and liked it. Over all it is a nice product, very clean, works just like other reviews described that I read before I made the purchase. For a portable tool it is very good.
  1212. My wife gave this to me for Christmas and it lasted through 3 months of every other day use. Ill designed (I am an engineer) gets dirty in hard to clean crevices. Died after too brief a life.   1213. my wife bought one of these to try some two years ago, and i've been using it regularly since. it finally died on me few weeks ago. i found out from other reviews, it's not recommended to use rechargeable batteries. i started using rechargeables in this unit few months ago, and i noticed the batteries really started to \\"stick\\" inside after a while. i can't say this was 100% the cause, but it seems like a logical possibility for the unit not turning on anymore. but considering the price, two years was a pretty good duration.<br /><br />design-wise, this irrigator was truly portable, where the nozzle came off easily and fit nicely inside the casing when not in use. the switch was in a place that got easily turned on by accident, which i see is a possible place for improvement.<br /><br />so aside from slight design flaw and rechargeable battery problems, i was quite happy with this item. i just ordered a new one, after trying an oral irrigator by toilettree products ([[ASIN:B00E6AR2J2 2nd Generation Professional Rechargeable ToiletTree]] which died on me after only two weeks of use.

  1228. I am really surprised at how well this works. My teeth feel just as clean, if not cleaner, than traditional flossing. I resisted getting a water flosser for a long time because of the price, but then this model came on Amazon Deals and I had to get it!<br /><br />Use: Use a coin to twist open the battery cap (trust me, your finger nails will thank you). Fill up with water before attaching the flosser tip because it fits in your sink less awkwardly. Click on the flosser to use it. Start with the lowest setting and key point here: DO NOT POINT AT BACK OF THROAT WHEN TURNING ON! or you will seriously injure your throat if you are accidentaly on a high setting. when done, run the flosser till all the water is out, and then open the tank to get rid of what remains. Remove the flosser tip by pressing the button on the side (I was lazy and didnt read the instructions and was freaking out because I couldnt get it off)<br /><br />Definitely recommend because its fun and it works!

  1234. Purchased this irrigator at the behest of my dentist. Not this particular model, but told to get one. I needed something small as I have a very small counter and sink; I would have preferred a plug in model but they all seemed to take up too much counter space. Works simply enough: fill the \\"trough\\" with tap water, put the mouth piece in your mouth at the angle to clean around your teeth and turn it on. Be sure to keep your mouth closed or you will have water spraying all over the place . . . takes a bit of practice . . . It does not take long (a few weeks) for the battery power to weaken and the spray weaken along with it--my first complaint. My second may come later . . . it does appear to be cheaply made and I have little hope that it will last me a long time--but it may surprise me. It does get out food debris that brushing may not get --seems to be a good thing to start off with as part of your dental hygiene.
  1235. I hate flossing. I dont even know how to do it properly. Now especially with braces, this has become a chore. With this product, it makes it so easy! and it really gets my mouth clean. Plus, its easy to travel with.
  1236. this well designed, compactable, nesting and powerful enough irrigator gets used twice a day. dont feel clean with out it. far superior to flossing. gets out stuff that brushing cant even hope to reach. best 30$ ever spent.<br />any nay-sayer doesnt know what they are talking about, or they got a faulty unit. if they are smart, and know how to use it correctly, and arent a complainer by nature, there is nothing bad that can really be said about this particular unit.<br />by the way its WAY better than the oral B irrigator, and the ora-jet which I bought first at CVS.<br />this one has been the right solution for me.

This thing keeps my braces clean without much hassle, and it folds down into a convenient travel size - which means I can bring it to work on days when I have appts., etc. and not have to worry about it. The tank is enough to go around the inside and outside of my teeth with some to spare.<br /><br />Cons - it does chomp down on batteries quite a bit, although I can say I'v gotten three solid weeks of use out of a set of Duracells - and that's with twice, sometimes three times daily use, but you can hear the difference in the pump between when they were new and now. I would like to try some rechargeables to see how they do.

Tilt the whole thing upside down, rotate it, turn it from side to side, while it is on, to get all the excess water out from all parts of the device. Doesn't hold much water but for me, it's just about right. What I particularly love about this unit is that it comes apart. You can clean the inside out. After a while, even a little bit of standing water will get yucky inside and leave gunk especially if you have hard water. I had other handhelds that you could not clean out. I certainly didn't want to be putting yucky water on my gums. I'm trying to prevent gum infections. All you have to do is just pull on it (you won't break it) and you can wipe out the entire inside of the water container. I highly recommend!

  1300. I'm really shocked at any negative reviews for this irrigator because I've been quite pleased with it, despite being nervous about making the great leap from string floss.<br /><br />No, it's not as powerful as the counter-top models but really, how strong does the water stream need to be? I am cleaning my teeth, not pressure-washing the house. Yes, I too would have liked a jet stream but I doubt it's actually necessary. Once upon a time, I used to insist on firm, stiffly bristled toothbrushes. It turned out that my aggressive brushing was hurting, not helping my innocent and sensitive gums. Sometimes things are just counterintuitive and I believe that's the case with the water pressure.<br /><br />My dentist had recommended a water irrigator instead of string floss but I resisted and finally confessed that I am incapable of keeping myself or my bathroom dry when armed with a WaterPik. It was banished long ago to our appliance graveyard, for the safety of one and all. Surprisingly, she laughed and told me she was just as hopeless until, through the miracle of technology, they had finally invented a portable, waterproof irrigator that could be used in the shower. Glory hallelujah, my problems were solved and at a very reasonable price.<br /><br />Using it in the shower is ridiculously easy. Yes, it has to be refilled at least once but who cares? It's a breeze to refill so I consider it a non-issue. I bring a bottle of water into the shower with me and can refill the tank in seconds. If it held any more water, it would likely be less comfortable to grasp. Now that I've used it for awhile, I'm much more adept and am capable of using it at the sink without drenching myself or my surroundings, to the relief of my family and attire.<br /><br />Some have complained about mold in the tank but I haven't had a similar issue. Of course, that may be because I add some Listerine to my water. It's good for my breath and apparently, good for my irrigator. My last checkup was aces so I'm even happier with my device and wouldn't trade it for any of the counter-top models.p was aces so I'm even happier with my device and wouldn't trade it for any of the counter-top models.

  1318. I bought this as a Deal of the Day for about $26, and for the most part, have been pretty satisfied with the performance of Panasonic's version of the WaterPik. This implement can be a little messy to use at times, but it does generate a powerful stream of water that can be quite useful in cleaning debris from between your teeth and gums.<br /><br />The unit is collapsible so it can be easily stored or transported, and it has a compartment for storing the nozzle. Once extended, the nozzle and water reservoir become accessible. At either of the two power settings, the reservoir holds enough water to run for less than a minute. During a typically cleaning, I usually have to refill the unit a couple of times.<br /><br />The jet of water is pretty powerful, and does a good job of blasting out trapped particles. I normally use the irrigator after I bush and floss my teeth, as the final finishing touch. The cleaning process can get a little protracted, but it is well worth it if you can avoid an expensive dental procedure. Cosmetic crowns, or a root canal, could easily cost over a thousand dollars.<br /><br />This product can also help provide advance indication about possible problem areas. If your gums that are sensitive to a jet of water, there could be something happening there that may require attention, and you can alert your dentist or hygienist to take a look.<br /><br />The shape of the unit isn't the most convenient to handle, and the power switch can be little hard to operate, particularly if your hands are wet. Two AA batteries are required to power the unit. Battery life is good, but not great. Rechargeable cells are not recommended, but I use them anyway. [[ASIN:B003OC74SW Replacement nozzles]] are available, so the irrigator can be shared. Just be sure you are able to identify your nozzle.<br /><br />As the 1278th Amazon reviewer, it's quite easy to for me give the Panasonic EW-DJ10 a 5 star rating, especially as I saved purchasing it on sale.

  1325. This is, in my experience, the best water flosser I have used to date. I am a dentist, and I have tested several water flossers, eventually giving up the use of them, to return to regular flossing. Until I found this product, that is.<br /><br />This product does exactly that which is mentioned in the product description -- floss quickly & effectively without the mess and fuss that one would experience with regular flossing. (provided that the user is cognizant & compliant with the user instructions provided with the irrigator). I have used several brands of water flossers, and this is, by far, the best. I am a person who flosses at least twice a day, and despite me being diligent and consistent with this, my first flossing session with this irrigator did cause minor bleeding in one area, which indicates that I was probably not flossing correctly in this area, despite all the effort put into flossing daily.<br /><br />For anybody that does not understand: The bleeding that one may see with initial use of this product is simply an indication of inflammation of the gums that was existent prior to irrigation. With proper, and regular use, this (initial) bleeding should subside, in which case you will know that the irrigator IS doing what it was meant to do. It would be a mistake to stop using the product when bleeding is evident. It would then be better to opt for the lower setting so as to get comfortable with the irrigator.<br /><br />For me, the only downside is that the product is battery-operated. I personally would prefer the rechargeable variety (to save on batteries), but this was hardly enough to lay me off from at least trying this product. And I have yet to be dissappointed. I would highly recommend this product to anyone that wants a compact, easy to use dental irrigator. I would also definitely buy this product again, if the need arises.

Major plus point is that it is extremely portable and everything folds to an adult palm size. This of course means that the reservoir is not adequate and I end up filling it 3-4 times on one use. I am okay with this as filling it up is very easy. A nice trick would be to put a little mouth wash with water (though the manual DISCOURAGES putting any chemicals except water inside).
  1339. I've tried this product before and after brushing my teeth...I never see food particles come out or really feel a difference. I suppose it's still doing something beneficial as opposed to not doing it at all but not really sure it's worth buying. In it's defense I do have tight teeth so maybe others will see better results?
  1340. The price is reasonable, the unit is compact and powerful and it gets out stuff you didn't know was stuck in there. Leaves your mouth feeling clean. Probably best to use any irrigator before brushing.<br /><br />Definitely recommended.
  1341. This item is suitable for use to bring in the bathroom.<br />When I use this for the first time, blood came out from the gums.But was very refreshing.

  1344. Excellent product. I use it twice a day. Keep your dental cost low by brushing, dental flossing, and water pick. Also protable so you can take it with you when you travel.
  1345. We purchased this unit for our 6 year old who is having some early orthodontic work done to try to avoid future problems. She recently got a palate expander installed that covers a few teeth and goes across the roof of her mouth. We purchased a water pik type of product at the suggestion of the orthodontist to help us keep her teeth and the palate expander clean. We wanted something simple that we could use at home or while traveling. This had some features that we thought would work well for our situation.<br /><br />Pros:<br />♦ Does a good job of helping her clean out her teeth. Was able to get some sticky smores out after a girl scouts outing pretty easily.<br />♦ It is pretty easy to control for her (besides the switch).<br />♦ Convenient for travel. Folds up pretty small and has a place to hold the tip.<br />♦ Waterproof. We have her use it in the shower.<br /><br />Cons:<br />♦ Switch is a little difficult for a 6 year old to work, but not too bad.<br />♦ Small reservoir. It takes two fillings to clean out her whole mouth, even on the low setting.<br />♦ Has a steady stream, but more of a pulsing action.<br />♦ Extremely messy for a child to use. We have her use it in the shower every night so that she doesn't get water all over the bathroom.<br /><br />Overall, we are please with this purchase. We didn't want a counter top unit, so this was the next best thing that offered good performance and travel options. It is extremely messy for a small child to use, which is to be expected. We found that since it is waterproof, the best option for us was for our daughter to use it in the shower every night which makes for easy cleanup and no water all over the bathroom. I couldn't imagine having a 6 year old try to control this unit or even a counter top version made for kids outside of the shower. It would get everywhere, so the waterproof nature of this product is perfect for us.
  1346. Great flosser if you hate using the string floss! It is very powerful and works well!

  1363. I hate flossing, so this thing is great. One for the purse, one for the shower, one for the sink. Love it!
  1364. I love that this little oral irrigator is low tech. You fill the reservoir, stick the nozzle in your mouth, and away you go! It's easy to figure out. One fill of the reservoir provides the perfect go around for teeth and gums. My mouth definitely feels cleaner after using it, and my dentist seems to be happy with the results.<br /><br />Why only 4 stars? I don't think the power is optimal for oral hygiene. My gums have not bled or even been sore from Day One of using it, and the pressure doesn't seem to be any greater than just a vigorous swish and rinse. It's comparable to the water jet dentists used to used to rinse one's mouth after cleaning. It's pleasant, but not aggressive.<br /><br />This is a nice addition to the oral hygiene arsenal, but I'm not sure it's the perfect one.
  1365. This is my 3rd Panasonic. I've had two previous versions and I went with this one because of the reliability of the previous models. Both of the previous Panasonics I've owned did not die...they just get a bit &#34;grungy&#34; after a year or two of use.<br /><br />Although some reviews and some Panasonic documentation suggests not to use rechargeable batteries, I have ALWAYS used AA rechargeable batteries in these irrigators and feel they work well, with no degradation in irrigator performance.<br /><br />Suggestion for longer/cleaner life: take the reservoir, pump unit, and nozzle apart and put them in your dishwasher every month or so. It will take care of any buildup, crud, etc. Make sure to take the batteries out and put the battery cover back on so no water gets inside the battery compartment. Also, take it apart after each use and lay on a paper towel near the sink...nightly drying out also helps keep it clean.<br /><br />A great value and I see the great results in the dentist chair!
  1366. Excellent travel 'water pic' type device. Does a good job for away from home use. At home, I'd still recommend a good plug in unit with a larger water supply and a bit more power. I use a counter top Water Pic, but I'm sure there are other good units to be had. Away from home though, I don't think you'll find a much better one than this Panasonic unit.
  1367. This was my 3rd try for a travel oral irrigator - by far the best yet. It is light enough for travel, I also take it to work, and the water pressure is good - feels as good as when I use my electric water-pik. The irrigator tip stores in the side of the water tank to make it smaller for travel and a replacement tip can be ordered if you require a spare. The batteries last too, I quite often have to refill the water tank as I require more time - but this is no big deal as it fills quickly and easily. I have used this regularly in the past 6 months and only just replaced the two batteries. I liked this so much I purchased one for my daughter, and highly recommended to friends that travel. Perfect for gifting.

  1389. Reading some of the negative reviews of this item prior to purchase almost kept me from purchasing it. I am glad I ignored the negative and focused on the positive. I had no problem putting the batteries in - have had it for a couple of months and have had no problems at all. I think the amount of water it holds is sufficient for a good cleaning.   1392. Two great things about this unit, in addition to the fact that it's powerful enough at the high speed to clean between my teeth perfectly:<br /><br />1) It collapses down to fit in my toiletry kit.<br />2) It uses standard &#34;AA&#34; batteries. Most of the other portable irrigators use a permanently installed rechargeable battery which usually start to fail after a year or two and then the thing is useless. The batteries last a long time in this unit, and then you just replace them and you're back to full power. Sometimes simpler is really better.
  1393. I like the product because it is small, I can take it anywhere in the world and all I need are batteries. Waterpik offers something similar, but you will need a converter and the product itself is too big and too heavy when you have only limited baggage on a flight
  1394. 1. I absolutely love the collapsible and portable design. I need to always have an oral irrigator close to me due to my dental pockets and the resulting severe consequences if I don't clean them out in a timely fashion. This product's compact design allows me to conveniently carry it in my backpack pretty much everywhere I go; not just on my frequent business trips but even for a day out in the city, for example. Plus, having blown out an AC power-supply based irrigator while traveling internationally, it's good to never have to deal with that again. So this is pretty much a lifeline for me.<br /><br />2. In comparison to other similar products, it provides much greater accessibility to clean all the nooks and crevices. This is again critical since these irrigators tend to accumulate a lot of slime; and the idea of using a filthy product to spray water into tight spaces between my teeth doesn't seem appealing or hygienic. This reason alone has led me to dump competing products in the past.<br /><br />3. Unlike some other oral irrigation 'systems', this one does not come with a whole slew of different attachments. But having used such systems in the past, those additional attachments have felt gimmicky and a wasteful overkill anyway. By focusing on the essentials with this one, the designers have managed to keep the cost contained.<br /><br />4. I did experience a loss of jet propulsion power 18 months into using it, which I tied back to the nozzle needing replacement. The replacement was not expensive and proved to be a good means to keep on with use of the product without having to buy new.<br /><br />5. As far as uses outside of its obvious, life-saving use for people with severe and impossible-to-reach dental pockets, it also helps get out tiny particles that brushing or even conventional flossing can't get to. But to be clear, it replaces neither of those other 2 activities; with each one (brushing, flossing, oral irrigator) providing its own set of benefits. My daily routine comprises of all 3 at night-time; and if I have time, all 3 after lunch too. If I'm pressed on time at work, I may use this as a quick consolatory replacement for a full floss. Used this way, I can claim with satisfaction that I'm almost completely free of morning bad breath; and my dentist always gives me high marks for my oral hygiene as well..

  1424. Previously I had a battery operated Conair InterPLak WJ3CS for years and it's great, but wanted to try this one and the results are much better in the power department, it uses two AA batteries in contrast with conair which uses 3 AA and the stream of water is a bit more powerfull than my older conair with the option to go stronger.<br /><br />With one downfall the water container is half the size of the conair , like 165 ml something like that, the conair has 300 ml and you can put a bit more. But is enough to do my top teeth refill and do the lower teeth. It takes less space in my sink area than the conair.<br /><br />On how to operate this unit is not tricky, just use your common sense, otherwise read the manual.<br /><br />Think this unit is sipping water with a straw, so you need to keep the bottom of the irrigator always down and figure out how to clean every single space between your teeth.<br /><br />Somebody mentioned on a review to not use rechargeable batteries with this unit,I checked the manual and it is stated like so but I've used other products with Eneloop batteries, specially a waterproof shaver, my older Conair dental irrigator and never had a problem with these batteries, so I take the risk and use it with these batteries because this thing eats batteries alive. And I don't want to become Duracell dependent.
  1425. Great u delivered it spot on, on time. Thanks for that. The thinghy itself is a little flumsy... It's ok i guess... It's working fine though.

  1435. We've been using these for over 15 years (this is the third model). The motor brushes wear out in about 3 or 4 years, and cannot be repaired. We just buy another one. This model is the best they've made in terms of features. If alkaline batteries are too strong for you, start out with rechargeable batteries until your gums get healthier. Also, this model is two-speed. Also great for traveling. Biggest advantage is from flushing small food particles from under gumline -- there's really no other way to get them out.
  1436. I wanted a small unit that did not take up too much space on my counter top. This perfectly fits the bill.   1453. It is pretty good. For the first few years, it let me travel and water floss. The minor and important design flaw is the water tank can't be open up to clean inside.   1455. I only had the unit for 5 days, but after double checking with flossing in some of the harder to reach areas, the water jet seems to work just as well as the dental floss tape to dislodge stuff from in-between the teeth. The irrigator also seems to have opened up the areas between the teeth since the tape is now getting in between the teeth a little easier (has never happened in several years of just flossing).<br /><br />The unit is easy to use (got it going without even reading the instructions) and the tank lasts for half the mouth (meaning for ex. lower teeth, front and back) at the slower speed, which for me is not a problem since the tank is so easy to fill up. I personally felt the higher speed was a little too strong, so stuck with the slower one. I've been using it with water only followed up by rinsing the mouth with mouth wash, same as when I did with regular flossing.<br /><br />So far I'm happy with the purchase, this is much more convenient than flossing, but will update review after I see my dentist again in a few months.<br /><br />Edit 6/19/14: Went to the dentist today. All periodontal readings improved, there was also almost no bleeding during the probing. Also the hygienist had much less trouble doing the cleaning - she usually has to be pretty forceful between the teeth, but today was quick and easy. At least to me the oral irrigator is proven to be a good replacement for flossing tape and the process takes maybe 1/3 or 1/4 of the time. Very happy with purchase.

  1497. I have never used a device like that, and bought it from amazon since it was on sale at the moment because I was curious about it. It was easy to set up, I needed a coin to unscrew the battery compartment, then I had to pull out the green water tank, insert the spraying end, fill the tank with water and it was ready to go. The power button is conveniently located at the side, and I am able to use it without looking. It is a big slider, and it works well even with my hand being wet. There are two settings, I used only lower setting since I do have problems with my gums, and this is what the instructions suggest. YOu need to insert it in your mouth, bend your head down, and turn the appliance on. Keep your mouth slightly open so water has a way to go, you would not be able to hold the whole tank contents in your mouth! Even on low setting, the water stream is quite powerful. There is a learning curve on how to make sure you get to all your teeth without spraying the whole bathroom, but it is possible. Make sure you fully extend the water tank, or it might collapse when water gets low.
  1498. I purchased this after having another cordless one from Waterpik. The problem with the Waterpik is that their rechargeable batteries are not replaceable. Mine stopped charging after about 1 1/2 years and is now completely useless since it doesn't even operate when plugged in (by design). Waterpik does not sell any cordless models where the battery can be replaced so I opted to instead purchase the Panasonic one since you can replace the batteries. This Panasonic one operates and is just as effective as the Waterpik accept that the Panasonic is more portable. I recommend the Panasonic if you want cordless but do not want to have to replace the entire unit when the batteries need to be replaced.

  1552. Be warned: The battery cap was virtually impossible to remove when the item arrived. I'm a very experienced handyman but the cap had me stumped. If I was the proverbial little old lady then there is no way I could have gotten the cap off. The cause of the problem is that the cap has a rubber gasket that keeps water out, and that rubber welded itself to the walls of the battery compartment. If there were batteries inside, removing the cap would have been a matter of tapping the unit on a hard surface and the weight of the batteries would have forced the cap off, but with an empty compartment it's a different story. There is nowhere on the cap to grip it with pliers and the cap is flush with the surface of the unit.
  1553. Using the Irrigator twice per day I had to replace the batteries in 10 days. After two cycles of battery replacements the unit would not pump water out althoght I had even replaced with new batteries. Back to Waterpik.
  1554. I bought this for travel and it works just perfectly! I love that it can use AA batteries. Great find and great buy!
  1555. Exactly what I was looking for! Perfect for travel! Easy to use, and clean!<br /><br />Especially enjoy that it is cordless!
  1556. I like it, used to buy similar one at Amazon, didn't work only 2 weeks after I received it, Panasonic is an reliable brand, hope this one is better.
  1557. I have been using this product for well over a year now, and it's doing a remarkable job. My dentist checkups have improved since using the waterpik. I especially like that it is battery operated which makes it so easy to take on trips. This has traveled with me to San Diego, Iowa and Mississippi; lightweight and easy to pack. Great product, especially for the price.
  1558. Like surfing with my teeth- Kowabanga!
  1559. I used it in the office. It just perform quite similar to waterpik model which use at home. Just one thing, the stock batteries can last 4 times of use only. It took me $$$$$ to buy 1900mah eneloop batteries. sadly, they will last 5 times, but anyway they are rechagible.

  1568. To keep it dry after use takes some time. It is messy to fill and even more so when using it so be careful not to take it out of your mouth until after you shut it off as, although it sounds like it is done, it isn't necessarily and you may end up squirting the wall, mirror or floor! If you position it correctly it does a good job cleaning inbetween your teeth especially if you are dental floss challenged like I am. I don't think a more expensive one would be any better performance-wise but the shape of this one is a bit bulky. I will continue to use it until something different comes along.
  1569. I love the idea of this product but water gets sprayed everywhere
  1570. I just received this product and immediately tried it out. For someone who doesn't floss (weird phobia of mine, can't take the sound or feeling), this is perfect. It cleaned between my teeth very well and only freaked me out a little bit. The pressure was good, I even used it on the lower setting and it did its job. It's easy to refill, so the 40-second run-time is not a problem.
  1571. I have braces on my teeth - ulk-I'm to old for braces, but anyway, I was taking a week long trip and since I love my oral irrigator I have at home, I knew I would miss it. so I got this and it really did the trick. I got all that crap our of around my braces and teeth. It packs nicely. the only problem - which I now know, is to clean the outside of the container before packing it up. I must of had something on the side when I closed it and that got inside, and was a pain to clean. But I still love it.
  1572. I think I like it? I don't know. After 3 weeks of using this thing, I still don't have a comfortable way of using this product. I have no pattern that works. I have some gripes, but maybe they're not gripes. Maybe I'm just not a very good Oral Irrigator user.<br /><br />This thing is big. It's cumbersome to hold and maneuver through your mouth. I'm a big guy, with big hands, and it's uncomfortable even for me to hold. I feel like the design makes it difficult to move this thing to effectively clean all of my gums. I can get the outside gums fine, but the inside ones are really difficult for me to reach, for some reason.<br /><br />For it's size, this tank runs out of water quickly. It says something about &#34;45 seconds&#34; in the product description, but that's if you're using the low setting. If you're using the high setting, it's much less than that.<br /><br />The unit is collapsible. The white section that contains the motor squashes down and is contained within the blue section for easier storage. When you extend it, you'll feel a little click that tells you the unit is locked in a fully-open position.....or so you think. The suction from the motor drawing out the water from the blue tank causes it to kind of close down on itself in the middle of you using it. That may not sound like a big deal, because you can re-extend it, but trust me, when you're using it, it's very annoying.<br /><br />The function of the unit seems good, from what I can tell. I feel like I have a very clean mouth when I've finished using it. The design of this thing does make me think it's going into my travel bag, and I'm going to have to purchase a different product with a larger tank, and more comfortable wand-type sprayer.
  1573. This Oral Irrigator was recommended to me by my oral hygenist, and I guess I need to read the descriptions better - I was surprised to find it was battery operated! 2AA's - come with it. So - I'm not sure how long the batteries will last, but so far it's 3 weeks. Installing the batteries was &#34;ok&#34; in that the 1/4 turn battery cover was reluctant to spring out, but it eventually did, I put a touch of 3 in 1 on it to aid future battery changes. Other than this all is well. Plenty of cleaning power on the slow speed, haven't felt the need to use the high speed. The water reservoir capacity is adequate - I find I need at least two fills per cleaning. This irrigator should be conevenient for those who travel because the top part can be pushed down into the water reservoir when empty, for compactness.

  1610. I bought this portable irrigator in March of 2013. It worked really well for one year and three months. Now, it seems to have an issue with its motor. At first, I thought it was the battery and replaced it with a new one. Still worked very slowly. Then, I replaced the battery with a lithium battery. Still works very slowly--at about 10 percent power. When the unit was working, it was great. I wear braces and almost have to have an irrigator to use 2 or 3 times a day--even when I travel. And this unit was my travel irrigator. My main one is a Water Pic--and it is wonderful. This one was great for travel. However, seeing as how I used it only for travel and at our cabin in the mountains, I think its shelf life is not very good. Will I get another? Probably--but only because I need a compact travel irrigator--and this one seems to be the only one I can find. Let's hope the next one lasts longer. Are you reading these reviews, Panasonic?? I hope so.
  1611. This is a great travel product. The stream is not as strong as I like it to be for daily use, but for a battery-powered travel irrigator, this is perfect. I love that it compacts down to a smaller size, and it is very easy to fill up with water. It is a bit bulky and may be difficult for smaller hands to hold as noted in other reviews, but I have not had difficulty with it. One issue I have run into is the water reservoir does not always stay extended - it sometimes likes to pop up while I'm using the device. It does not interfere with its operation that I can tell, however, so it's usually a simply matter of just pulling it back down into place. It does have self-storage for a head, but it can only store one head. If you travel with one or more other people and all wish to use the product, you would have to carry the additional heads separately. The reservoir is adequate for one person, depending on how much irrigation you need/want. For the most part, the reservoir has been sufficient for me to clean my entire mouth, but if I have had to refill a time or two after eating a meal that leaves more particles between my teeth. Regardless, this irrigator does a great job of getting stuck items out of your teeth and leaving your mouth feeling clean.

  1634. First off let me say I've owned a Waterpik home unit for several years and love it. I picked up their travel version and couldn't stand it.<br /><br />This Panasonic unit has a quick/easy refill, folds up and takes replaceable batteries (you can always put rechargable AA's in it, at least they're serviceable). Already way ahead of Waterpik travel.<br />The attachment stores in the side of the unit and it closes up into a nice small size.<br />2xAA batteries last a little over one month of daily use. As they wear down there is a noticable decrease in the waterjet power, at which point setting #1 or 2 both feel weak.<br />It generally takes 2 fills per cleaning.<br /><br />Though I'm guessing this rarely happens: one of the times I filled it and it wouldn't spray for more than a few seconds, eventually figured out the filler tube in the reservoir was still curled up instead of resting on the bottom. Shaking it pulled it down. You can also pull the water reservoir off for cleaning or service.<br /><br />The attachment pic it came with is different than the main Waterpik one. It has somewhat of a jagged design and I'm used to more rounded ends. However, I haven't noticed it during use at all. This is probably intentional so there's not too much water pressure on your gums. (I only use the #1 setting most of the time anyway)<br /><br />It seems of quality construction, especially for the cost. I expect it to last many years.

  1686. Love it! Can't live without it. The big advantage: I can take it with me everywhere. Other's have complained that the reservoir rune out too quickly. What are you kidding me? It take about 5 seconds to reload. Way better than a big clunky &#34;Waterpic&#34;.
  1687. When I first put it together it seemed awkward, but it was designed for travel so can't have everything prefect.
