  1688. I have been using this since 2010. It does a fantastic job of getting &#34;stuff&#34; out from between teeth and in the gums. It's very portable and fits into a quart size zip lock bag for travel. This has greatly reduced the time and discomfort when the dentist cleans my teeth.<br /><br />The tank holds plenty of water (and mouthwash) for a cleaning. No cords is even better. I use Panasonic envelop rechargeable batteries (the best I have ever used). A charged set of batteries lasts more than 2 weeks.<br /><br />I usually mix a capful of Listermint mouthwash with warm water in the unit. I think this keep the unit cleaner as well as my mouth. I also will clean the unit with a bleach (Chlorox) solution of less than a half an ounce per tank about 2x per year to kill anything that might start growing even though I use the listermint mouthwash in the tank. For the Chlorox cleaning, I fill the tank with the diluted solution, run about 1/3 of the solution through the unit. Let the unit sit for at least 1 hour and then run the rest of the solution through it. I then flush several tanks of plain water through the unit to clear any bleach residue.
  1689. I'm 42 and just got braces. I wasn't sure what to expect and saw this pretty cheap as a daily deal. It works great. Really knocks the food stuff out of my braces. It doesn't get in the way. I use it for only about a minute or so each time, so I don't imagine the batteries will wear down all the quickly, but haven't had it long enough to find out. But, if they do, I have plenty of rechargeables.
  1690. I've been using panasonic irrigators for years, this model is lightweight, portable, uses 2 AA batteries, has 2 settings (for sensitive gums) you'll be amazed at the stuff that gets flushed out you never knew were in there. the first few uses may cause a little bleeding but not to worry, its because the trapped food and bacteria causes irritation/ inflammation on the gums. when theyre healthy again they will not bleed when squirted so just keep at it

  1699. As an adult with braces in the past two years I became fanatical about keeping my mouth healthy. In those two years I bought and used 2 different rechargable Waterpik flossers, both of which refused to charge after a few months (a common problem) and became expensive trash. When replacing the second one I decided to go with a non-rechargeable model and purchased the Panasonic instead. I am very pleased. It's more compact, takes up less space in my bathroom, comes apart for cleaning, and packs a punch.<br /><br />My braces are gone but I'm still using my Panasonic because it does a fantastic job and it helps to keep my gums healthy.   1700. This Panasonic upgraded irrigator with two speeds is a much improved version of the two others I have owned. I like the disconnect feature on the units tip.   1701. I've used the Panasonic Oral Irrigator for about 10 years. [[ASIN:B0027LSEPS Panasonic Oral Irrigator EW-DJ10-A]]. I used several Water Pik products before moving to Panasonic, but I stopped using Water Pik products because they turned into junk about 15 years ago.<br /><br />To extend the life of this Panasonic unit by 2 or 3 times, pull it apart right away after each time you use it. That is, pull off the water resevoir, open up the plug where you fill it with water, and store the resevoir upside down, so it dries. Then turn the rest of the unit on and let all the water squirt out of the body and pump. Try to get out as much as you can. Then store the unit that way until you're ready to use it again. Don't reassemble it again until you're ready to use it again.<br /><br />A little vaseline or similar lubricant on the O rings every few months is also a good idea.<br /><br />And one other thing, even drying it out the way I suggest, mold still tends to grow inside the resevoir and in several places on the outside -- even on the Jet Pik handle. Use an old toothbrush and some Peroxide to clean or wipe off any mold you see. You can also soak the Jet Pick in Peroxide overnight to clean it out and help keep mold from growing in there. And if you have a piece of wire or small enough brush to fit into/through the Jet Pik, use that too, to help clean it out.<br /><br />Follow these tips and you'll have a cleaner Water Pik that lasts a lot longer. Good luck. It's a great product!
  1702. I liked this so much for travel that I used it for every day. I guess that was too much because now it only has half the power with fresh batteries. So I had to knock off 2 stars. And it's a battery buster and says not to use rechargeables. So I got a waterpik and now use this only for travel. Tips: keep it clean always. It helps to soak the tank in 1/2 bleach and water for a few minutes after extended use. Be sure to read how to clear the water out after use or you'll get a musty smell, especially if you store the brush with water in it. Perfect for travel because it's light weight when folded up. Worth it if you travel a lot and don't want to miss. Just don't use it every day or it won't apparently last as long.
  1703. Better than the ones which are electric. So much more convenient to use with batteries. I can take it with me everywhere when I travel because it doesn't take up much space in my suitcase. I wouldn't be without it!

I put in new batteries and I'm thrilled to say that it now works like new. I always love the way it makes my teeth and mouth feel. Plus it's so easy to use and the price is right.   1722. [Update: It just stopped working. And, like many products offered to the U.S. Consumer, it can't be fixed or recycled, so it will end up in a landfill.]<br /><br />I bought this because my full size &#34;Hydrofloss&#34; product is too big and heavy to travel with.<br />It's inexpensive, portable, lightweight and works pretty well.<br /><br />* It's not as powerful as the the plug-in model I keep at home, but it will suffice for a one or two week trip.<br />* If I were traveling for a longer period, I would schlep my full size model.<br />* The little hinged door that opens for fulling is flimsy, I expect it will break after repeated use and Panasonic will not have a replacement.<br />* If you want to be thorough, you may need to fill two or three times per use.<br />* It's a good idea to let this dry out completely before re-use, and clean periodically with vinegar to avoid bacteria build-up.
  1723. Messier tha a traditional water pick. But it serves the purpose when you are away from home.
  1724. GOOD:<br />I own this water flosser. It is so much easier to use and encourages you to floss when you are lazy or rushing. It is not as effective as string based (polytetrafluoroethylene or nylon) flossing. So, a combination of both is better for oral health.<br /><br />BAD:<br />* As battery runs out, strength of the water jet also fades gradually. Electronics design flaw.<br />* I came across users complaining about mold and mildew issues for other models (where water is stored permanently and flosser plugged in to the wall socket). I always empty my flosser and let it dry. Yet I noticed pink mildew inside my nostril. It is hard to see. Put a torch on its outside surface and see through the hole. Fix is simple. Get regular cooking vinegar from your grocery store. Immerse the nostril in vinegar for a day. It cleans itself. Note, this is a common issue with all water based flossers.

  1732. My gum was swollen because my braces were tightened and since I started using this a week ago I have already noticed significant improvement. This irrigator is best when you can't floss yet because of time constraints (or you're just being lazy like me). But I'd recommend combining the use of this with conventional flossing for an optimal result.<br /><br />You can't really go wrong with the quality of its performance compared to its price. It's portability is also an indispensable feature if you're on the road all the time. However, this may not be for the picky ones as this doesn't have all the fancy tips like Waterpik. (It says in the manual that came with it - but who reads it?)
  1733. About 90% of the oral irrigators on the market are designed for families sharing family-size bathrooms.<br /><br />For those of us living alone - about 28% of all Americans - finding a place on the counter-tops of our typically tiny bathrooms for these behemoths is a major challenge. Plus, we also have to be concerned about where to plug them in. In short these irrigators just don't work for singles living alone in small spaces.<br /><br />Until it was discontinued about 4 years ago, I happily used the battery-powered Water Pik Traveler 350W. Key feature was the reservoir which - for traveling - inverted over the base power unit. The irrigator tip was connected to the base with a hose which neatly coiled, and stored in the reservoir, when not in use. Measuring only about 4\\" x 3\\" x 1,\\" the 350W could almost fit in palm of my hand.<br /><br />Since my 350W gave out, (plug-in models simply are not an option for me), I've tried probably every battery-operated travel irrigator. There are a couple available with separate reservoirs. But none compare to the old 350W with respect to power.<br /><br />Most of the currently-available travel models have done away with the hose and attach the tip directly to the battery case atop the reservoirs.<br /><br />I find these bulky units very difficult to use - as has been commented on by earlier reviewers. Hard to hold onto. Nearly impossible to direct the water jet to where you want it. Especially hard to get to the backs of teeth.<br /><br />Also, like other reviewers, I find the unavoidable drip of used water spit onto the unit and sometimes down my arm very distasteful.<br /><br />Also, agree with other reviewers, the Panasonic is impossible to clean. Can't imagine what the designers were thinking. Once you deal with the mold problem in the bottom of the reservoir, all kinds of nooks and crannies need to be cleaned.<br /><br />Every time I change the batteries - about every 3 weeks - I remove the reservoir (don't be afraid to pull really hard) and soak it in bleach. I clean all the crevices with toothpicks and Q-tips. Takes me about 15 min.<br /><br />Have also learned that the Panasonic must be kept vertically at all times since the battery section is not water tight.<br /><br />So - if you angle the unit - for example, while trying to get to the backs of your teeth, you will be compromising the life of the batteries.<br /><br />Learned after a couple of trips to remove the batteries completely - unless you can figure out a way to keep it vertical the entire time you are in transit.<br /><br />The two Panasonics I've had died after about one year. The pumps just stop working. But in each case, the Warranty has been honored. Keep the box!<br /><br />So.... the Panasonic is the best of the Travel irrigators currently available. It's the only one I have found which has any power at all. But that's the best I can say about it. Wish someone would bring back something like the Water Pik 350W.
  1734. Love this product! I would highly recommend it! I was actually looking for something very compact for traveling, however, to my surprise was much bigger than I thought it would be, but I absolutely love it!
  1735. It was usable from arrival until Feb 16, 2015 when it ceased to operate. I reinserted batteries after a long flight - would not respond. Batteries were tested in a flashlight, still effective. I returned home March 8, now responding to your review request. Need to reread original documents. Returnable? Replace?
  1736. I've had this for about a month, using it nightly, and I'm pretty pleased. I don't have anything to compare it to, as it is my first irrigator. One downside is that it is pretty loud, but it doesn't bother me. The reservoir is enough water to do my entire mouth.
